text: In the beginning, God created the universe.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the earth was as yet unformed and desolate, with the surface of the ocean depths shrouded in darkness, and while the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters,
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “Let there be light!” So there was light.
speaker: God

text: God saw that the light was beautiful. He separated the light from the darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: calling the light “day,” and the darkness “night.” The twilight and the dawn were day one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be a canopy between bodies of water, separating bodies of water from bodies of water!”
speaker: God

text: So God made a canopy that separated the water beneath the canopy from the water above it. And that is what happened:
speaker: Narrator

text: God called the canopy “sky.” The twilight and the dawn were the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the water beneath the sky come together into one area, and let dry ground appear!” And that is what happened:
speaker: God

text: God called the dry ground “land,” and he called the water that had come together “oceans.” And God saw how good it was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let vegetation sprout all over the earth, including seed-bearing plants and fruit trees, each kind containing its own seed!” And that is what happened:
speaker: God

text: Vegetation sprouted all over the earth, including seed-bearing plants and fruit trees, each kind containing its own seed. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twilight and the dawn were the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be lights across the sky to distinguish day from night, to act as signs for seasons, days, and years,
speaker: God

text: to serve as lights in the sky, and to shine on the earth!” And that is what happened:
speaker: Narrator

text: God fashioned two great lights—the larger light to shine during the day and the smaller light to shine during the night—as well as stars.
speaker: Narrator

text: God placed them in space to shine on the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to differentiate between day and night, and to distinguish light from darkness. And God saw how good it was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twilight and the dawn were the fourth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the oceans swarm with living creatures, and let flying creatures soar above the earth throughout the sky!”
speaker: God

text: So God created every kind of magnificent marine creature, every kind of living marine crawler with which the waters swarmed, and every kind of flying creature. And God saw how good it was.
speaker: Narrator

text: God blessed them by saying, “Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the oceans. Let the birds multiply throughout the earth!”
speaker: God

text: The twilight and the dawn were the fifth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth each kind of living creature, each kind of livestock and crawling thing, and each kind of earth’s animals!” And that is what happened:
speaker: God

text: God made each kind of the earth’s animals, along with every kind of livestock and crawling thing. And God saw how good it was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let us make mankind in our image, to be like us. Let them be masters over the fish in the ocean, the birds that fly, the livestock, everything that crawls on the earth, and over the earth itself!”
speaker: God
Narrator

text: God blessed the humans by saying to them, “Be fruitful, multiply, fill the earth, and subdue it! Be masters over the fish in the ocean, the birds that fly, and every living thing that crawls on the earth!”
speaker: God

text: God also told them, “Look! I have given you every seed-bearing plant that grows throughout the earth, along with every tree that grows seed-bearing fruit. They will produce your food.
speaker: God

text: I have given all green plants as food for every wild animal of the earth, every bird that flies, and to every living thing that crawls on the earth.” And that is what happened.
speaker: God

text: Now God saw all that he had made, and indeed, it was very good! The twilight and the dawn were the sixth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: With this, the universe was completed, including all of its vast array.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the seventh day, God had completed the work he had been doing, so on the seventh day he stopped working on everything that he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it God stopped working on everything that he had been creating.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the records of the universe at its creation. On the day that the Lord God made the universe,
speaker: Narrator

text: no shrubs had yet grown in the meadows of the earth and no vegetation had sprouted, because the Lord God had not sent rain on the earth and there were no human beings to work the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, an underground stream would arise out of the earth and water the surface of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God formed the man from the dust of the ground, breathed life into his lungs, and the man became a living being.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God planted a garden in Eden, toward the east, where he placed the man whom he had formed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God caused every tree that is both beautiful and suitable for food to spring up out of the ground. The tree of life was also in the middle of the garden, along with the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: A river flows from Eden to water the garden, and from there it divides, becoming four branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the first one is Pishon—it winds through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold of that land is pure; bdellium and onyx are also found there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the second river is Gihon— it winds through the entire land of Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third river is named the Tigris— it flows to the east of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God took the man and placed him in the Garden of Eden in order to have him work it and guard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God commanded the man: “You may freely eat from every tree of the garden,
speaker: God

text: but you are not to eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, because you will certainly die during the day that you eat from it.”
speaker: God

text: Later, the Lord God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make the woman to be an authority corresponding to him.”
speaker: God

text: After the Lord God formed from the ground every wild animal and every bird that flies, he brought each of them to the man to see what he would call it. Whatever the man called each living creature became its name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man gave names to all the livestock, to the birds that fly, and to each of earth’s animals, but there was not found a strength corresponding to him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so the Lord God caused a deep sleep to overshadow the man.
When the man was asleep, he removed one of the man’s ribs and closed up the flesh where it had been.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God formed the rib that he had taken from the man into a woman and brought her to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the man exclaimed,
“At last! This is
    bone from my bones
        and flesh from my flesh.
This one will be called ‘Woman,’
    because she was taken from Man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Therefore a man will leave his father and his mother and cling to his wife, and they will become one flesh.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though both the man and his wife were naked, they were not ashamed about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Shining One was more clever than any animal of the field that the Lord God had made. He asked the woman, “Did God actually say, ‘You are not to eat from any tree of the garden’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We may eat from the trees of the garden,” the woman answered the Shining One,
speaker: Narrator

text: “but as for the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the garden, God has said, ‘You are not to eat from it, nor are you to touch it, or you will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You certainly will not die!” the Shining One told the woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Even God knows that on the day you eat from it, your eyes will be opened and you’ll become like God, knowing good and evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw that the tree produced good food, was attractive in appearance, and was desirable for making one wise, she took some of its fruit and ate it. Then she also gave some to her husband who was with her, and he ate some, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, they both understood what they had done, and they became aware that they were naked. So they sewed fig leaves together and made loincloths for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard the voice of the Lord God as he was walking in the garden during the breeze of the day, the man and his wife concealed themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God called out to the man, asking him, “Where are you?”
speaker: God

text: “I heard your voice in the garden,” the man answered, “and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Who told you that you are naked?” God asked. “Did you eat fruit from the tree that I commanded you not to eat?”
speaker: God

text: The man answered, “The woman whom you provided for me gave me fruit from the tree, and I ate some of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord God asked the woman, “What did you do?”
“The Shining One misled me,” the woman answered, “so I ate.”
speaker: God

text:
The Lord God told the Shining One,
“Because you have done this,
    you are more cursed than all the livestock,
        and more than all the earth’s animals,
You’ll crawl on your belly
    and eat dust
        as long as you live.
speaker: God

text:
“I’ll place hostility between you and the woman,
    between your offspring and her offspring.
He’ll strike you on the head,
    and you’ll strike him on the heel.”
speaker: God

text:
He told the woman,
“I’ll greatly increase the pain of your labor during childbirth.
    It will be painful for you to bear children,
“since your trust is turning toward your husband,
    and he will dominate you.”
speaker: God

text:
He told the man,
“Because you have listened to what your wife said,
    and have eaten from the tree about which I commanded you,
        ‘You are not to not eat from it,’
cursed is the ground because of you.
    You’ll eat from it through pain-filled labor
        for the rest of your life.
speaker: God

text:
It will produce thorns and thistles for you,
    and you’ll eat the plants from the meadows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will eat food by the sweat of your brow
    until you’re buried in the ground,
        because you were taken from it.
You’re made from dust
    and you’ll return to dust.”
speaker: God

text: Now Adam had named his wife “Eve,” because she was to become the mother of everyone who was living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God fashioned garments from animal skins for Adam and his wife, and clothed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the Lord God said, “Look! The man has become like one of us in knowing good and evil. Now, so he won’t reach out, also take from the tree of life, eat, and then live forever—”
speaker: God

text: therefore the Lord God expelled the man from the garden of Eden so he would work the ground from which he had been taken.
speaker: God

text: After he had expelled the man, the Lord God placed winged angels at the eastern end of the garden of Eden, along with a fiery, turning sword, to prevent access to the tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Adam had sexual relations with his wife Eve. She became pregnant and gave birth to Cain. She said, “I have given birth to a male child—the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she did it again, giving birth to his brother Abel. Abel shepherded flocks and Cain became a farmer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, after a while, Cain brought an offering to the Lord from the fruit that he had harvested,
speaker: Narrator

text: while Abel brought the best parts of some of the firstborn from his flock. The Lord looked favorably upon Abel and his offering,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but he did not look favorably upon Cain and his offering.
When Cain became very upset and depressed,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord asked Cain, “Why are you so upset? Why are you depressed?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do what is appropriate, you’ll be accepted, won’t you? But if you don’t do what is appropriate, sin is crouching near your doorway, turning toward you. Now as for you, will you take dominion over it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, Cain told his brother Abel, “Let’s go out to the wilderness.” When they were outside in the fields, Cain attacked his brother Abel and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later, the Lord asked Cain, “Where’s your brother Abel?”
“I don’t know,” he answered. “Am I my brother’s guardian?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What did you do?” God asked. “Your brother’s blood cries out to me from the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you’re more cursed than the ground, which has opened to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever you work the ground, it will no longer yield its produce to you, and you’ll wander throughout the earth as a fugitive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “My punishment is too great to bear,” Cain told the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’re driving me from the soil today. I’ll be hidden from you, and I’ll wander throughout the earth as a fugitive. In the future, whoever finds me will kill me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told him, “This won’t happen, because whoever kills you will suffer seven times the vengeance.” Then the Lord placed a sign on Cain so that no one finding him would kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Cain left the presence of the Lord and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Cain had sexual relations with his wife. She became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Cain founded a city and named it after his son Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Irad was born to Enoch. Irad fathered Mehujael, and Mehujael fathered Methushael, and Methushael fathered Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Lamech married two wives. One was named Adah and the other was named Zillah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who became the ancestor of those who live in tents and herd livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother was named Jubal; he became the ancestor of all those who play the lyre and the flute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-cain, who became a forger of bronze and iron work. Tubal-cain’s sister was Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lamech told his wives,
“Adah and Zillah, listen to what I have to say:
    You wives of Lamech, hear what I’m announcing!
I’ve killed a man for wounding me,
    a young man for bruising me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For if Cain is being avenged seven times,
    then Lamech will be avenged 77 times.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later on, after Adam had sexual relations with his wife, she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, because
“God granted me another offspring to replace Abel,
    since Cain murdered him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth also fathered a son, whom he named Enosh. At that time, profaning the name of the Lord began.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the historical record of Adam’s generations.
When God created mankind,
    he made them in his own likeness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Creating them male and female,
    he blessed them
and called them humans
    when he created them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Adam had lived 130 years, he fathered a son just like him, that is, according to his own likeness, and named him Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam lived another 800 years, fathering other sons and daughters after he had fathered Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Seth had lived 105 years, he fathered Enosh.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Enosh, Seth lived 807 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enosh had lived 90 years, he fathered Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Kenan, Enosh lived 815 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived a total of 905 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Kenan had lived 70 years, he fathered Mahalalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Mahalalel, Kenan lived 840 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived a total of 910 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mahalalel had lived 65 years, he fathered Jared.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Jared, Mahalalel lived 830 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jared had lived 162 years, he fathered Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Enoch, Jared lived 800 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enoch had lived 65 years, he fathered Methuselah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Methuselah, Enoch communed with God for 300 years and fathered other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch lived a total of 365 years,
speaker: Narrator

text: communing with God—and then he was there no longer, because God had taken him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he fathered Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Lamech, Methuselah lived 782 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he fathered a son,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom he named Noah, because he said, “May this one comfort us from our work, from pain that is caused by our manual labor, and from the ground that the Lord has cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Noah, Lamech lived 595 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Noah had lived 500 years, he fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after the population of human beings had increased throughout the earth, and daughters had been born to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: some divine beings noticed how attractive human women were, so they took wives for themselves from a selection that pleased them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “My Spirit won’t remain with human beings forever, because they’re truly mortal. Their lifespan will be 120 years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nephilim were on the earth at that time (and also immediately afterward), when those divine beings were having sexual relations with those human women, who gave birth to children for them. These children became the heroes and legendary figures of ancient times.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw that human evil was growing more and more throughout the earth, with every inclination of people’s thoughts becoming only evil on a continuous basis.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord regretted that he had made human beings on the earth, and he was deeply grieved about that.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “I will annihilate these human beings whom I’ve created from the earth, including people, animals, crawling things, and flying creatures, because I’m grieving that I made them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Lord was pleased with Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the family records of Noah: Noah was a righteous man. Blameless during his times, Noah communed with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah fathered three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: By this time, the earth had become ruined in God’s opinion and filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: God looked at the earth, observing how corrupt its population had become, because the entire human race had corrupted itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God announced to Noah, “I’ve decided to destroy every living thing on earth, because it has become filled with violence due to them. Look! I’m about to annihilate them, along with the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So make yourself an ark out of cedar, constructing compartments in it, and cover it inside and out with tar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the ark like this: 300 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a roof for the ark, and finish the walls to within one cubit from the top. Place the entrance in the side of the ark, and build a lower, a middle, and an upper deck.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For my part, I’m about to flood the earth with water and destroy every living thing that breathes. Everything on earth will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I will establish my own covenant with you, and you are to enter the ark—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to bring two of every living thing into the ark so they may remain alive with you. They are to be male and female.
speaker: Narrator

text: From birds according to their species, from domestic animals according to their species, and from everything that crawls on the ground according to their species—two of everything will come to you so they may remain alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your part, take some of the edible food and store it away—these stores will be food for you and the animals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah did all of this, precisely as God had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Noah, “Come—you and all your household—into the ark, because I’ve seen that you alone are righteous in this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to take with you seven pairs of every clean animal, a male and its mate, and two of the unclean animals, a male and its mate;
speaker: Narrator

text: along with seven pairs of the flying birds, male and female, in order to keep their offspring alive on the surface of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days from now I’ll send rain on the earth for 40 days and 40 nights, and I’ll destroy every living creature that I’ve made.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah did everything that the Lord commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was 600 years old when water began to flood the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives entered the ark with him before the flood waters arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: From both clean and unclean animals, from birds, and from everything that crawls on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: two by two, male and female, they entered the ark to join Noah, just as God had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days later, the flooding started.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventeenth day of the second month, when Noah was 600 years old, all the springs of the great deep burst open, the floodgates of the heavens were opened,
speaker: Narrator

text: and it rained throughout the earth for 40 days and 40 nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that very day, Noah entered the ark with his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, Noah’s wife, his sons’ three wives with them,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with every species of wild animal, livestock, crawling creature, bird, and every creature that has wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two of each living creature entered the ark with Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The males and females of each living creature entered the ark, just as God had commanded. Then the Lord sealed them inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood continued throughout the earth for 40 days, while the flood waters increased, lifting the ark so that it rose above the surface of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood waters continued to surge, increasing throughout the earth, while the ark floated on the surface of the flood water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood water surged even higher throughout the earth, until all the highest mountains under the sky were covered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood waters rose 15 cubits above the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every living thing on earth died—flying creatures, livestock, wildlife, all creatures that swarm over the earth, and all human beings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that breathed and everything that had lived on dry land died.
speaker: Narrator

text: All existing creatures that had lived on the surface of the ground were annihilated, from humans to livestock, from crawling creatures to birds of the sky. They were wiped off the earth. Only Noah remained, along with those who were with him in the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood waters surged over the earth for 150 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: God kept Noah in mind, along with all the wildlife and livestock that were with him in the ark. God’s Spirit moved throughout the earth, causing the flood waters to subside.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water sources from the ocean depths were blocked and the floodgates of the heavens were closed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the flood waters steadily receded, diminishing completely by the end of the 150 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat on the seventeenth day of the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood water continued to recede until the tenth month, when, on the first of that month, the tops of the mountains could be seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: After 40 days, Noah opened the window of the ark that he had built
speaker: Narrator

text: and sent out a raven. It went back and forth as the flood water continued to evaporate throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, he sent a dove out from the ark to see whether the water that covered the land’s surface had completely receded,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the dove could not yet find a place to rest, so it returned to Noah on the ark, since water still covered the land. Noah reached out his hand and took the dove back into the ark with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah waited another seven days and sent the dove out from the ark again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The dove returned to him in the evening, but in its beak there was an olive leaf that it had plucked! So Noah knew that the flood waters had decreased on the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited seven more days and sent the dove out again, but it did not return to him anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the six hundred and first year of Noah’s life, during the first month, the flood water began to evaporate from the land. Noah then removed the ark’s cover and saw that the surface of the land was drying.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month, the ground was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke to Noah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s time for you, your wife, your sons, and your sons’ wives who are with you to leave the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring out with you every living creature—including the flying creatures, animals, and everything that crawls on the ground—so they may disperse throughout the land, be fruitful, and multiply throughout the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives emerged.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every animal, every crawling thing, every flying creature, and everything that moves on the earth emerged from the ark by groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah built an altar to the Lord and offered burnt offerings on it from every clean animal and every clean bird.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord smelled the pleasing aroma, he told himself, “I will never again curse the land because of human beings—even though human inclinations remain evil from youth—nor will I destroy every living being ever again, as I’ve done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Never again, as long as the earth exists,
    will sowing and harvest,
cold and heat,
    summer and winter,
        and day and night ever cease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God blessed Noah and his sons and ordered them, “Be productive, multiply, and fill the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the living creatures of the earth will be filled with fear and terror of you from now on, including all the creatures that fly in the sky, everything that crawls on the ground, and all the fish of the ocean. They’ve been assigned to live under your dominion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every living, moving creature will be food for you. Just as I gave you green plants before, so now you have everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you are not to eat meat with its life—that is, its blood—in it!
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, I will certainly demand an accounting regarding bloodshed, from every animal and from every human being. I’ll demand an accounting from every human being for the life of another human being.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Whoever sheds human blood,
    by a human his own blood is to be shed;
because God made human beings
    in his own image.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now as for you, be productive
    and multiply;
spread out over the land
    and multiply throughout it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, God told Noah and his sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pay attention! I’m establishing my covenant with you and with your descendants after you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with every living creature that is with you—the flying creatures, the livestock, and all the wildlife of the earth that are with you—all the earth’s animals that came out of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish my covenant with you: No living beings will ever be cut off again by flood waters, and there will never again be a flood that destroys the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God also said, “Here’s the symbol that represents the covenant that I’m making between me and you and every living being with you, for all future generations:
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve set my rainbow in the sky to symbolize the covenant between me and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever I bring clouds over the earth and the rainbow becomes visible in the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll remember my covenant between me and you and every living creature, so that water will never again become a flood to destroy all living beings.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the rainbow is in the clouds, I will observe it and remember the everlasting covenant between God and all living beings on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God also told Noah, “This is the symbol of the covenant that I’ve established between me and everything that lives on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah’s sons who came out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Ham later fathered Canaan.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These three were Noah’s sons, and from these men the whole earth was repopulated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah, a man of the soil, was the first to plant and farm a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: He drank some of the wine, got drunk, and lay down naked right in the middle of his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ham, who fathered Canaan, saw his father’s genitals and told his two brothers outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shem and Japheth took their father’s cloak, laid it across both their shoulders, and walking backwards, they both covered their father’s genitals. Their faces were turned away, and they did not see their father’s genitals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah sobered up and learned what his youngest son had done to him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he said,
“Canaan is cursed!
    He will be the lowest of slaves to his relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also said,
“Blessed be the Lord God of Shem,
    and may Canaan be his slave.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Noah had lived a total of 950 years, he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the records of Noah’s sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, to whom descendants were born after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Japheth’s descendants included Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gomer’s descendants included Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Javan’s descendants included Elisha, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim,
speaker: Narrator

text: from whom the coastal nations spread into their own lands and nations, each with their own language and family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ham’s descendants included Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cush’s descendants included Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca.
Raamah’s descendants included Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush fathered Nimrod, who became the first fearless leader throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He became a fearless hunter in defiance of the Lord. That is why it is said, “Like Nimrod, a fearless hunter in defiance of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His kingdom began in the region of Shinar with the cities of Babylon, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he went north to Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth-ir, and Calah,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with Resen, which was located between Nineveh and the great city of Calah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Egypt fathered the Ludites, the Anamites, the Lehabites, the Naphtuhites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Pathrusites, the Casluhites (from which came the Philistines), and the Caphtorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan fathered Sidon his firstborn, along with the Hittites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
Later, the Canaanite families were widely scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Canaanite border extended south from Sidon toward Gerar as far as Gaza, and east toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are Ham’s descendants, listed by their families, each with their own lands, language, and family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem, Japheth’s older brother, also had descendants. Shem was the father of the descendants of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem’s sons included Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aram’s descendants included Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arpachshad fathered Cainan, Cainan fathered Shelah, and Shelah fathered Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Eber were born two sons. One was named Peleg, because the earth was divided during his lifetime. His brother was named Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were Joktan’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their settlements extended from Mesha towards Sephar, the eastern hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are Shem’s descendants, listed by their families, each with their own lands, language, and family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Noah’s sons, according to their records, by their nations. From these people, the nations on the earth spread out after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a time when the entire earth spoke a common language with an identical vocabulary.
speaker: Narrator

text: As people migrated westward, they came across a plain in the region of Shinar and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told each other, “Come on! Let’s burn bricks thoroughly.” They used bricks for stone and tar for mortar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Come on! Let’s build ourselves a city and a tower, with its summit in the heavens, and let’s make a name for ourselves so we won’t be scattered over the surface of the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Lord descended to look over the city and the tower that the humans were building.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Look! They are one people with the same language for all of them, and this is only the beginning of what they will do. Nothing that they have a mind to do will be impossible for them!
speaker: Narrator

text: Come on! Let’s go down there and confuse their language, so that they won’t understand each other’s speech.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord scattered them abroad from there over the surface of the whole earth, so that they had to stop building the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it was called Babylon, because there the Lord confused the language of all the earth, and from there the Lord scattered them over the surface of the entire earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the family records of Shem. When Shem had lived 100 years, he fathered Arpachshad two years after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem lived 500 years after he fathered Arpachshad and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arpachshad had lived 35 years, he fathered Cainan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After he fathered Cainan, Arpachshad lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters, and then died.
Cainan lived 130 years and fathered Shelah. After he fathered Shelah, Cainan lived 330 years and had other sons and daughters, and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shelah had lived 30 years, he fathered Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Eber, Shelah lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eber had lived 34 years, he fathered Peleg.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Peleg, Eber lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Peleg had lived 30 years, he fathered Reu.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Reu, Peleg lived 209 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reu had lived 32 years, he fathered Serug.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Serug, Reu lived 207 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Serug had lived 30 years, he fathered Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Nahor, Serug lived 200 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Nahor had lived 29 years, he fathered Terah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he fathered Terah, Nahor lived 119 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Terah had lived 70 years, he fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the family records of Terah: Terah fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran fathered Lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran died during his father’s lifetime in the land of his birth, that is, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah. She was the daughter of Haran, who was the father of Milcah and Iscah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarai was barren, so she had not borne children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (Haran’s son), and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram’s wife, and they journeyed together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan. But when they had gone as far as Haran, they settled there,
speaker: Narrator

text: where Terah died at the age of 205 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Abram, “You are to leave your land, your relatives, and your father’s house and go to the land that I’m going to show you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll make a great nation of your descendants, I’ll bless you, and I’ll make your reputation great, so that you will be a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll bless those who bless you, but I’ll curse the one who curses you, and through you all the people of the earth will be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram left there, as the Lord had directed him, and Lot accompanied him. Abram was 75 years old when he left Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, all the possessions they had accumulated, and the servants he had acquired while living in Haran. Then they set out to go to the land of Canaan. When they arrived in the land of Canaan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram traveled through the land to the place called Shechem, as far as the oak of Moreh. At that time the Canaanites were in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord appeared to Abram and said, “I’ll give this land to your descendants.” So Abram built an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there Abram traveled on to the hill country east of Bethel and set up his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the Lord and called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram traveled on, continuing into the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a famine in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to live because the famine was so severe.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was about to enter Egypt, he told his wife Sarai, “Look, I’m aware that you’re a beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘She is his wife.’ Then they’ll kill me, but allow you to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please say that you are my sister, so things will go well for me for your sake. That way, you’ll be saving my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Abram was entering Egypt, the Egyptians noticed how beautiful Sarai was.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh’s officials saw her, they brought her to the attention of Pharaoh and took the woman to Pharaoh’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: He treated Abram well because of her, so Abram acquired sheep, oxen, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord afflicted Pharaoh and his household with severe plagues because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh summoned Abram and asked, “What have you done to me! Why didn’t you tell me that she was your wife?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I took her as a wife for myself? Now, here is your wife! Take her and get out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh assigned men to Abram, and they escorted him, his wife, and all that he had out of the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram traveled from Egypt, along with his wife and everyone who belonged to his household—including Lot—to the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abram had become quite wealthy in livestock, silver, and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He journeyed by stages from the Negev to Bethel, the place where his tent had formerly been, between Bethel and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: where he had first built an altar. There Abram called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also had flocks of sheep, herds, and tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land could not support them living together, because they had so many livestock that they could not stay together.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was strife between the herdsmen in charge of Abram’s livestock and the herdsmen in charge of Lot’s livestock. Also, at that time the Canaanites and the Perizzites were living in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram told Lot, “Please, let’s not have strife between you and me, or between your herdsmen and my herdsmen, since we are relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t the whole land available to you? Let’s separate: If you go to the left, then I will go to the right; if you go to the right, then I will go to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot looked around and noticed that the whole Jordan plain as far as Zoar was well-watered like the garden of the Lord or like the land of Egypt. (This was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot chose for himself all the Jordan plain. Then Lot traveled eastward, and they separated from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram lived in the land of Canaan, while Lot settled in the cities of the plain, setting up his tent in the vicinity of Sodom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men of Sodom were particularly evil and sinful in their defiance of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Lot had separated from Abram, the Lord told Abram, “Look off to the north, south, east, and west from where you’re living,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I’m going to give you and your descendants all of the land that you see—forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll make your descendants as plentiful as the specks of dust of the earth, so that if one could count the specks of dust of the earth, then your descendants could also be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up! Walk throughout the length and breadth of the land, because I’m going to give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram moved his tent and settled beside the oaks of Mamre that are by Hebron, where he built an altar to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time when Amraphel was king of Shinar, Arioch was king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer was king of Elam, and Tidal was king of the Goiim,
speaker: Narrator

text: they engaged in war against King Bera of Sodom, King Birsha of Gomorrah, King Shinab of Admah, King Shemeber of Zeboiim, along with the king of Bela (which was also known as Zoar).
speaker: Narrator

text: All of this latter group of kings allied together in the Valley of Siddim (that is, the Salt Sea).
speaker: Narrator

text: They were subject to Chedorlaomer for twelve years, but they rebelled in the thirteenth year.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer and the kings with him came and defeated the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, the Emites in Shaveh-kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Horites in the hill country of Seir, near El-paran by the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next they turned back and came to En-mishpat (which was also known as Kadesh) and conquered all the territory of the Amalekites, along with the Amorites who lived in Hazazon-tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela (which was also known as Zoar) prepared for battle in the Valley of Siddim
speaker: Narrator

text: against King Chedorlaomer of Elam, King Tidal of Goiim, King Amraphel of Shinar, and King Arioch of Ellasar—four kings against five.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits, so when the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some of their people fell into them, while the rest fled to the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The conquerors captured all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah, including their entire food supply, and then left.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took Abram’s nephew Lot captive, and confiscated his possessions, since he was living in Sodom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone escaped, arrived, and reported what had happened to Abram the Hebrew, who was living by the oaks belonging to Mamre the Amorite, whose brothers Eshcol and Aner were allied with Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram heard that his nephew had been taken prisoner, he gathered together 318 of his trained men, who had been born in his household, and they went out in pursuit as far as Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the night, Abram and his servants divided his forces, conquered his enemies, and pursued them as far as Hobah, north of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He recovered all the goods and brought back his nephew Lot, together with his possessions, the women, and the other people.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abram’s return from defeating Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with them, the king of Sodom went out to meet with him in the Shaveh Valley (that is, the King’s Valley).
speaker: Narrator

text: King Melchizedek of Salem brought out bread and wine, since he was serving as the priest of God Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Melchizedek blessed Abram and said,
“Abram is blessed by God Most High,
    Creator of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and blessed be God Most High,
    who has delivered your enemies
        into your control.”
Then Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Sodom told Abram, “Return the people to me, and you take the possessions for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram answered the king of Sodom, “I have made an oath to the Lord God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I will not take a thread or a sandal strap or anything that belongs to you, so you won’t be able to say, ‘I made Abram rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take nothing except what my warriors have eaten. But as for what belongs to the men who were allied with me, including Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre, let them take their share.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, a message came from the Lord to Abram in a vision. “Stop being afraid, Abram.” he said. “I myself—your shield—am your very great reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram replied, “Lord God, what can you give me since I continue to be childless, and the heir of my household is Eliezer from Damascus?
speaker: Narrator

text: Look!” Abram said, “You haven’t given me any offspring, so a servant born in my house is going to be my heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A message came from the Lord to him again: “This one will not be your heir. Instead, the child who will be born to you will be your heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord took him outside. “Look up at the sky and count the stars—if you can!” he said. “Your descendants will be that numerous.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram believed the Lord, and it was credited to him as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to him, “I am the Lord, who brought you from Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land as an inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, “Lord God, how will I know that I will inherit it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord responded, “Bring me a three-year-old cow, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram brought him all these animals and cut each of them in half, down the middle, placing the pieces opposite each other, but he did not cut the birds in half.
speaker: Narrator

text: When birds of prey swooped down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun began to set, Abram was overcome with deep sleep, and suddenly a frightening and terrifying darkness descended on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Abram, “You can be certain about this: Your descendants will be foreigners in a land that isn’t theirs. They will be slaves there and will be oppressed for 400 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I will judge the nation that they serve, and later they will leave there with many possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for you, you’ll die peacefully, join your ancestors, and be buried at a good old age.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your descendants will return here in the fourth generation, since the iniquity of the Amorites has not yet run its course.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun had fully set and it was dark, a smoking fire pot and a fiery torch passed between the animal pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day the Lord made this covenant with Abram: “I’m giving this land to your descendants, from the river of Egypt to the great Euphrates River—
speaker: Narrator

text: including the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abram’s wife Sarai had not borne a child for him. She had an Egyptian servant girl whose name was Hagar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Sarai told Abram, “You are well aware that the Lord has prevented me from giving birth to a child. Go have sex with my servant, so that I may possibly bear a son through her.”
Abram listened to Sarai’s suggestion,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Abram’s wife Sarai took her Egyptian servant, Hagar, and gave her as a wife to her husband Abram. This took place ten years after Abram had settled in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had sex with Hagar, and she became pregnant. When she realized that she was pregnant, she looked with contempt on her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarai told Abram, “My suffering is your fault! I gave you my servant so you could have sex with her, and when she discovered that she was pregnant, she looked on me with contempt. May the Lord judge between you and me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram answered Sarai, “Look, your servant is under your control, so do to her as you wish.” So Sarai dealt so harshly with Hagar that she ran away from Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord found her by a spring of water in the desert on the road to Shur.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hagar, servant of Sarai,” he asked, “Where are you coming from and where are you going?”
She answered, “I am running away from my mistress Sarai.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord told her, “You must go back to your mistress and submit to her authority.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord also told her, “I will greatly multiply your offspring, who will be too many to count.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, you are pregnant and will give birth to a son,” the angel of the Lord continued to say to her. “You will name him Ishmael, because the Lord has heard your cry of misery.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a man, he’ll be uncontrollable. He’ll be against everyone, everyone will be against him,and he’ll live in conflict with all of his relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she called the name of the Lord who spoke to her, “You are ‘God who sees,’ because I have truly seen the one who looks after me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why the spring was called, “The Well of the Living One who Looks after Me.” It was between Kadesh and Bered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hagar eventually gave birth to Abram’s son. Abram named his son whom Hagar bore Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was 86 years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael for Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram was 99 years old, the Lord appeared to Abram and announced, “I am God Almighty. Live in constant awareness that I’m always with you, and be blameless.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll establish my covenant between me and you, and I’ll greatly increase your numbers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram fell to the ground as God continued speaking to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, I’ve made a covenant with you. You will be the father of many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your name is no longer to be Abram. Instead your name will be Abraham, since I’ll make you the father of many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to cause you to have many descendants, and I’ll bring nations from you. Kings will come from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m establishing my covenant between me and you, and with your descendants who come after you, generation after generation, as an eternal covenant, to be your God and your descendants’ God after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll give to you and to your descendants the land to which you have traveled—all the land of Canaan—as an eternal possession. I will be their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God continued to speak to Abraham, “You and your descendants who are born in the future are to keep my covenant—that is, you and your descendants, generation after generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is my covenant that you are to observe, between me and you and your descendants: Every male among you is to be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are all to be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin, and this is to be the sign of the covenant between me and you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Generation after generation, every male among you is to be circumcised on the eighth day after his birth, including the servant born in your house or the one purchased from a foreigner, who is not of your offspring.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant born in your house or the one purchased with money is to be circumcised. My covenant is to remain in your flesh as an eternal covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any uncircumcised male who does not have the foreskin of his flesh circumcised on the eighth day after his birth is to be eliminated from his people because he has broken my covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God told Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you are not to call her Sarai any longer, because her name is to be Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless her. Furthermore, I will give you a son from her. I will bless her, so that nations, kings, and people will come from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham fell to the ground, laughed, and told himself, “Can a child be born to a 100-year-old man? Can a 90-year-old Sarah give birth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham responded to God, “If only Ishmael would live in constant awareness that you’re always with him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God replied, “No, but your wife Sarah will give birth to your son, and you are to name him Isaac. I’ll confirm my covenant with him as an eternal covenant for his descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for Ishmael, I’ve heard you. I’ll bless him, and he’ll have many descendants. I will multiply him greatly, he’ll father twelve tribal leaders, and I’ll cause his descendants to become a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to Isaac, I’ll confirm my covenant with him, to whom Sarah will give birth as your son at this time next year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: With that, God finished talking to Abraham, and ascended, leaving him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham took his son Ishmael and all the servants born in his house or purchased with his money—every male among the men of his household—and circumcised them that very day, just as God had spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was 99 years old when he was circumcised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised on that very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man born in his household—as well as those who had been purchased with money from a foreigner—was circumcised with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the Lord appeared to Abraham by the oaks belonging to Mamre. As Abraham was sitting near the entrance to his tent during the hottest part of the day,
speaker: Narrator

text: he glanced up and saw three men standing there, not far from him. As soon as he noticed them, Abraham ran from the tent entrance to greet them and bowed low to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lords,” he told them, “if I have found favor with you, please don’t leave your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll have some water brought to wash your feet while you rest under the tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll bring some food for you, and after that you may continue your journey, since you have come to visit your servant.”
So they replied, “Very well! Do what you’ve proposed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham hurried into the tent and told Sarah, “Quick! Take three measures of the best flour, knead it, and make some flat bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, Abraham ran to the herd, found a choice and tender calf, and gave it to the young men, who went off in a hurry to prepare it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took curds, milk, and the calf that had been prepared, placed the food in front of them, and stood near them under the tree while they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men asked him, “Where is your wife Sarah?”
“There, in the tent,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then one of them said, “I will certainly return to you in about a year’s time. By then, your wife Sarah will have borne a son.”
Now Sarah was listening at the tent entrance behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham and Sarah were old—really old—and Sarah was beyond the age of childbearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why Sarah laughed to herself, thinking, “After I’m so old and my husband is old, too, am I going to have sex?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and think, ‘Am I really going to bear a child, since I’m so old?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anything impossible for the Lord? At the time set for it, I will return to you—about a year from now—and Sarah will have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Sarah denied it. “I didn’t laugh,” she claimed, because she was afraid.
The Lord replied, “No! You did laugh!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, the men set out from there and looked out over Sodom. Abraham went with them to send them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Should I hide from Abraham what I’m about to do,” the Lord asked,
speaker: Narrator

text: “since Abraham’s descendants will become a great and powerful nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed through him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, I’ve made myself known to him in order that he may encourage his sons and his household that is born after him to keep the way of the Lord, and to do what is right and just, so that the Lord may bring about for Abraham what he has promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said, “How great is the disapproval of Sodom and Gomorrah! Their sin is so very serious!
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going down to see whether they’ve acted according to the protests that have reached me. If not, I wish to know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then two of the men turned away from there and walked toward Sodom, while Abraham remained standing in the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham approached and asked, “Will you actually destroy the righteous along with the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps there are 50 righteous ones within the city. Will you actually destroy it and not forgive the place for the sake of the 50 righteous that are found there?
speaker: Narrator

text: Far be it from you to do such a thing—to kill the righteous along with the wicked, so that the righteous and the wicked are treated alike! The Judge of all the earth will do what is right, won’t he?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “If I find 50 righteous people within Sodom, I’ll forgive the whole place for their sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham answered, “Look, even though I am only dust and ashes, I’ve ventured to speak to my Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What if there are five less than 50 righteous ones? Will you bring destruction upon the city because of those five?”
The Lord said, “I won’t destroy it if I find 45 there.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abraham continued to speak to him, asking, “What if 40 are found there?”
The Lord replied, “I won’t do it for the sake of those 40.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abraham then asked, “I hope my Lord will not be angry if I speak. What if 30 are found there?”
The Lord answered, “I won’t do it for the sake of those 30.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look,” Abraham said, “I’ve presumed to speak to my Lord… so what if 20 are found there?”
“For the sake of those 20,” the Lord responded, “I won’t destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Finally, Abraham inquired, “I hope my Lord will not be angry if I speak only once more. What if ten are found there?”
He replied, “For the sake of those ten I won’t destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he finished talking to Abraham, the Lord left and Abraham returned to where he had been sitting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two angels entered Sodom at sunset while Lot was sitting in the gate area of the city. When Lot saw them, he got up, greeted them, bowed low with his face to the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, “Look, my lords! Please come inside your servant’s house, wash your feet, and spend the night. Then you can get up early and be on your way.”
But they responded, “No, we would rather spend the night in the town square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot kept urging them strongly, so they turned aside and entered his house. He prepared a festival and baked unleavened flat bread for them, and they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before they could lie down, all the men of Sodom and its outskirts, both young and old, surrounded the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They called out to Lot and asked, “Where are the men who came to visit you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can have sex with them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot went outside to them, shut the door behind him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “I urge you, my brothers, don’t do such a wicked thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look here, I have two daughters who are virgins. Let me bring them out to you, and you may do to them whatever you wish, only don’t do anything to these men, because they’re here under my protection.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they replied, “Get out of the way! This man came here as a foreigner, and now he’s acting like a judge! So we’re going to deal more harshly with you than with them.” Then they pushed hard against the man (that is, against Lot), intending to break down the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angels inside reached out, dragged Lot back into the house with them, shut the door,
speaker: Narrator

text: and blinded the men who were at the entrance of the house, from the least important to the greatest, so they were unable to find the doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do you have anyone else here in the city?” the angels asked Lot. “A son-in-law? Sons? Daughters? Get them out of this place,
speaker: Narrator

text: because we’re going to destroy it. Their outcry has come to the attention of the Lord, so he sent us here to destroy it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot then went out and told his sons-in-law (they had married his daughters), “Get out of here! The Lord is going to destroy this city!” But his sons-in-law thought he was joking.
speaker: Narrator

text: As dawn was breaking, the angels pressured Lot. “Get going!” they told him. “Take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or you will be engulfed by the devastation that’s coming to this city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot kept lingering in the city, so the men grabbed his hand and the hands of his wife and two daughters (because of the Lord’s compassion for him!), brought them out of the city, and left them outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of them said, “Flee for your lives! Don’t look back or stop anywhere on the plain. Escape to the hills, or you’ll be swept away!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No! Please, my lords!” Lot pleaded with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your servant has found favor in your sight, and you have shown me your gracious love in how you have dealt with me by keeping me alive. I cannot escape to the hills, because I’m afraid the disaster will overtake me, and I’ll die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, there is a town nearby where I can flee, and it’s a small one. Let me escape there! It’s a small one, isn’t it? That way I’ll stay alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All right,” the angel replied to Lot, “I’ll agree with your request! I won’t overthrow the town that you mentioned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry up and flee there, because I cannot do anything until you get to that town.” Therefore the name of the town was called Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun had risen over the land about the time Lot reached Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord rained sulfur and fire out of the sky from the Lord on Sodom and Gomorrah,
speaker: Narrator

text: overthrowing those cities, all of the plain, and everyone who lived in the cities. He also destroyed the plants that grew out of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot’s wife looked back as she lingered behind him, and she became a pillar of salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham went early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the Lord earlier.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked off toward Sodom, Gomorrah, and the entire plain, and he saw smoke rising from the land like smoke from a furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was that, when God destroyed the cities of the plain, he remembered Abraham and brought Lot out from the midst of the destruction when he overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, Lot and his two daughters abandoned Zoar and settled in the hills because Lot was afraid to live in Zoar. He lived there in a cave, along with his two daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the firstborn told the younger one, “Our father is old, and there’s no man in the land to have sex with us, as everybody else throughout all the earth does.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come on! Let’s make our father drink wine, and then we’ll have sex with him so we can preserve our father’s lineage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they had their father drink wine that night, and the older one had sexual relations with her father, but he was not aware when she lay down or when she got up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the firstborn told the younger one, “Look! I had sex with my father last night. Let’s make him drink wine tonight again as well. Then you have sex with him, too. That way we’ll preserve our father’s lineage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night as well, so he was not aware when she lay down or when she got up.

text: That’s how both of Lot’s daughters became pregnant by their father.

text: The firstborn gave birth to a son and named him Moab, and he is the ancestor of the Moabites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben-ammi, and he is the ancestor of the Ammonites to this day.

text: Abraham traveled from there to the Negev and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While he was living in Gerar as an outsider,
speaker: Narrator

text: because Abraham kept saying about his wife Sarah, “She is my sister,” King Abimelech of Gerar summoned them and took Sarah into his household.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Abimelech in a dream during the night and spoke to him, “Pay attention! You’re about to die, because the woman you have taken is a man’s wife!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abimelech had not yet come near her, so he asked, “Lord, will you destroy an innocent nation?
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t he say to me, ‘She’s my sister’? And she also said, ‘He’s my brother.’ I did this with pure intentions and clean hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God replied to him in the dream, “I know that you did this with pure intentions, and it was I who kept you from sinning against me. Therefore, I didn’t allow you to touch her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, return the man’s wife. As a matter of fact, he’s a prophet and can intercede for you so you’ll live. But if you don’t return her, be aware that you and all who are yours will certainly die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech got up early the next morning, summoned all his servants, and told them all these things. The men became terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech called Abraham and asked him, “What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought such great sin against me and my kingdom? You’ve done things to me that ought not to have been done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech also asked Abraham, “What could you have been thinking when you did this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I thought that there’s no fear of God in this place,” Abraham replied, “and that they would kill me because of my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides, she really is my sister—she’s my father’s daughter, but not my mother’s daughter—so she could become my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When God caused me to journey from my father’s house, I asked her to do me this favor and say, ‘He’s my brother.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech took some sheep and oxen, and some male and female servants, gave them to Abraham, returned his wife Sarah to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Look! My land is available to you, so settle wherever you please.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech also told Sarah, “Look! I am giving your brother 1,000 pieces of silver to vindicate you in the eyes of all who are with you. As a result, you will be completely vindicated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham interceded with God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female servants so they could bear children,
speaker: Narrator

text: since the Lord had made all the women barren in Abimelech’s household on account of Abraham’s wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord came to Sarah, just as he had said, and the Lord did for Sarah what he had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah conceived and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age, at the very time that God had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham named his son who was born to him Isaac—the very one whom Sarah bore for him!
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day after his son Isaac had been born, Abraham circumcised him, just as God had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was 100 years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarah had said, “God has caused me to laugh, and all who hear about it will laugh with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She also said, “Who would have told Abraham that Sarah would nurse sons? Yet I have given birth to a son in my husband’s old age!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The child grew and eventually was weaned, so Abraham threw a tremendous banquet on the very day Isaac was weaned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, when Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian—whom Hagar had borne to Abraham—making fun of Isaac,
speaker: Narrator

text: she told Abraham, “Throw out this slave girl, along with her son, because this slave’s son will never be a co-heir with my son Isaac!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was very troubled about what was being said about his son,
speaker: Narrator

text: but God told Abraham, “Don’t be troubled about the youth and your slave girl. Pay attention to Sarah in everything she tells you, because your offspring are to be named through Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, I will make the slave girl’s son into a nation, since he, too, is your offspring.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So early the next morning, Abraham got up, took bread and a leather bottle of water, gave them to Hagar, and placed them on her shoulder. He then sent her away, along with the child. She went off and roamed in the Beer-sheba wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, the water in the leather bottle ran out, so she placed the child under one of the bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went and sat by herself about a distance of a bowshot away, because she kept saying to herself, “I can’t bear to watch the child die!” That’s why she sat a short distance away, crying aloud and weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard the boy’s voice, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven. He asked her, “What’s wrong with you, Hagar? Don’t be afraid, because God has heard the voice of the youth where he is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up! Pick up the youth and grab his hand, because I will make a great nation of his descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. So she went, filled the skin with water, and gave the boy a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was with the boy as he grew up. He settled in the wilderness and became an expert archer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later he settled in the desert area of Paran, and his mother chose a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: About that time, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, told Abraham, “God is with you in everything that you’re doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore swear an oath here by God that you won’t deal falsely with me, my sons, or my descendants. Just as I’ve dealt graciously with you, won’t you do so with me and with the land in which you live as a foreigner?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham replied, “I agree!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech’s servants had seized.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I don’t know who did this thing,” Abimelech replied. “You didn’t report this to me, and I didn’t hear about it until today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham took sheep and oxen and presented them to Abimelech, and the two of them made a covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham set aside seven ewe lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Abimelech asked Abraham, “What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set aside?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “You are to accept from me these seven ewe lambs as a witness that I have dug this well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore that place was called Beer-sheba, because the two of them swore an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: So after they had made a covenant in Beer-sheba, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, left and returned to Philistine territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beer-sheba, and there he called on the name of the Lord God Everlasting.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham resided as a foreigner in Philistine territory for a long period of time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sometime later, God tested Abraham. He called out to him, “Abraham!”
“Here I am!” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “Please take your son, your unique son whom you love—Isaac—and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him as a burnt offering there on one of the mountains that I will point out to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham got up early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his male servants with him, along with his son Isaac. He cut the wood for the burnt offering and set out to go to the place about which God had spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day he looked ahead and saw the place from a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham ordered his two servants, “Both of you are to stay here with the donkey. Now as for the youth and me, we’ll go up there, we’ll worship, and then we’ll return to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and placed it on his son Isaac. Abraham carried the fire and the knife. And so the two of them went on together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac addressed his father Abraham: “My father!”
“I’m here, my son,” Abraham replied.
Isaac asked, “The fire and the wood are here, but where’s the lamb for the burnt offering?”
