speaker: Narrator

text:
Abraham answered, “God will provide himself the lamb for the burnt offering, my son.”
The two of them went on together
speaker: Narrator

text: and came to the place about which God had spoken. Abraham built an altar there, arranged the wood, tied up his son Isaac, and placed him on the altar on top of the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he stretched out his hand and grabbed the knife to slaughter his son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just then, an angel of the Lord called out to him from heaven and said, “Abraham! Abraham!”
“Here I am,” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t lay your hand on the youth!” he said. “Don’t do anything to him, because I’ve just demonstrated that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only unique one, from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham looked up and behind him to see a ram caught by its horns in the thicket. So Abraham went over, grabbed the ram, and offered it as a burnt offering in place of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham named that place, “The Lord Will Provide,” as it is told this day, “On the Lord’s mountain, he will provide.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time from heaven
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “I have taken an oath to swear by myself,” declares the Lord, “that since you have carried this out and have not withheld your only unique son,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will certainly bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in heaven and as the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the gates of their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, through your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed my command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham returned to his servants and they set out together for Beer-sheba, where Abraham settled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after these things somebody told Abraham, “Look, Milcah has given birth to sons for your brother Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uz is his firstborn, Buz is his brother, and Kemuel is the father of Aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel fathered Rebekah. Milcah bore these eight sons to Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, his concubine Reumah gave birth to Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah lived for 127 years. That’s how long Sarah’s life was.
speaker: Narrator

text: She died in Kiriath-arba (that is, in Hebron) in the land of Canaan. Abraham went in to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham stood up from beside his dead wife and addressed the Hittites. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am an alien and an outsider among you. Give me a cemetery among you where I can bury my dead away from my presence.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hittites responded to Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to us, sir. You are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our burial tombs. None of us would refuse you his tomb for burying your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham rose and bowed before the Hittites, the people of the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and addressed them, “If you are willing that I should bury my dead out of my sight, listen to me and make a request of Zohar’s son Ephron on my behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me the cave of Machpelah that belongs to him, at the end of his field. He should sell it to me in your presence at full price for a burial site.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now since Ephron the Hittite had taken a seat there among the Hittites, he responded publicly to Abraham where the Hittites and everyone who was entering the gate of his city could hear him:
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, sir. Listen to me! I’ll give you the field, and I’ll give you the cave that’s in it. I give it to you publicly, in the sight of my people. Bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham bowed before the people of the land
speaker: Narrator

text: and then addressed Ephron so all the people of the land could hear him: “Please listen to me! I’m willing to pay the price of the field. Accept it from me, so I may bury my dead there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ephron answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sir, listen to me! The land is worth 400 shekels of silver, but what’s that between us? You may bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham agreed with Ephron, so he weighed out to Ephron the money to which he had agreed publicly while the Hittites were listening: 400 shekels of silver at the current merchant rate.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how Ephron’s field in Machpelah, east of Mamre—the field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were within the boundaries of the field—came to be deeded
speaker: Narrator

text: to Abraham in the presence of all the Hittites and everyone who was entering the city gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave at the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre (that is, in Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so the field with its cave was deeded by the Hittites to Abraham as a burial site.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham had grown old, was well advanced in age, and the Lord had blessed Abraham in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham instructed his servant, who was the oldest member of his household and in charge of everything he owned, “Make this solemn oath to me
speaker: Narrator

text: as a promise to the Lord, the God of heaven and earth, that you won’t acquire a wife for my son from the Canaanite women among whom I’m living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you are to go to my country and to my family and acquire a wife for my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What if the woman doesn’t want to come back with me to this land?” the servant asked. “Shouldn’t I have your son go to the land from which you came?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make sure not to take my son there,” Abraham replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord God of heaven, who brought me from my father’s house and from my family’s land, who spoke to me and promised me ‘I will give this land to your descendants,’ will send his angel ahead of you, and you are to acquire a wife for my son from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the woman isn’t willing to follow you, then you’ll be free from this oath to me. Just don’t take my son back there!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant made a solemn oath to his master Abraham regarding this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham’s servant took ten camels from his master’s herd of camels and left on his journey with all kinds of gifts from his master’s inventory. Eventually, he traveled as far as Aram-naharaim, Nahor’s home town.
speaker: Narrator

text: As evening approached, he had the camels kneel outside the town at the water well, right about the time when women customarily went out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s when he prayed, “Lord God of my master Abraham, help me to succeed today. Please show your gracious love to my master Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve stationed myself here by the spring as the women of the town come to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: May it be that the young woman to whom I ask, ‘Please, lower your jug so that I may drink,’ responds, ‘Have a drink, and I’ll water your camels as well.’ May she be the one whom you have chosen for your servant Isaac. This is how I’ll know that you have shown your gracious love to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he had finished speaking, Rebekah appeared. She was a daughter of Milcah’s son Bethuel. (Milcah was the wife of Abraham’s brother Nahor.) She approached the well, carrying a jug on her shoulder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman was very beautiful, young, and had not had sexual relations with a man. Going down to the spring, she filled her jug and turned for home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham’s servant ran to meet her and asked her, “Please, let me have a sip of water from your jug.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Drink, sir!” she replied as she quickly lowered her jug on her arm to offer him a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she also said, “I’ll also draw water for your camels until they’ve had enough to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She quickly emptied her jug into the trough and ran to the well to draw again until she had drawn enough water for all ten of the servant’s camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man stared at her in silence, waiting to see whether or not the Lord had made his journey successful.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a half shekel and two bracelets for her wrists, weighing 10 shekels and presented them to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked her, “Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father’s house for us to spend the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the daughter of Bethuel,” she answered. “He’s the son of Milcah and Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yes,” she continued, “we have plenty of straw and feed, as well as a place to spend the night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the man bowed down and worshipped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed be the Lord God of my master Abraham, who hasn’t held back his gracious love and faithfulness from my master! The Lord has led me to the house of my master’s relatives!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman then ran ahead and informed her mother’s household what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, who ran out to the man and met him at the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was, as soon as he saw the nose ring and bracelets on his sister’s wrists, and as soon as he heard what his sister Rebekah was saying about what the man had spoken to her, he went out to the man who was still standing by the camels at the spring!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come on,” Laban said. “The Lord has blessed you! So why are you standing out here when I’ve prepared some space in the house and a place for the camels?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant went to the house and unbridled the camels. They provided straw and feed for the camels and water for washing his feet and those of the men with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when they had prepared a meal and set it in front of him, he said, “I’m not eating until I’ve spoken.”
“Speak up!” Laban exclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m Abraham’s servant,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord has greatly blessed my master, so that he has become wealthy. He has provided him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: My master’s wife Sarah gave birth to my master’s son in her old age, and Abraham has given him everything that belongs to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: My master made me swear this oath: ‘You are not to select a wife for my son from among the daughters of the Canaanites in this land where I live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you are to go to my father’s household, to my relatives, and choose a wife for my son there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I asked my master, ‘What if the woman won’t come back with me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Abraham told me, ‘The Lord, who is with me wherever I go, will send his angel with you to make your journey successful. So you are to choose a wife for my son from my family, from my father’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only then will you be released from fulfilling my oath. However, when you come to my family, if they don’t give her to you, you’ll be released from fulfilling my oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So today I arrived at the spring and prayed, ‘Lord God of my master Abraham, if you wish to make the journey that I have traveled successful,
speaker: Narrator

text: here I am standing by the spring. May it be that the young woman who comes out to draw water, from whom I request a little water from her jug to drink,
speaker: Narrator

text: if she tells me to drink and also draws water for the camels, may she be the woman that the Lord has chosen for my master’s son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Before I had finished praying, along came Rebekah with her jug on her shoulder! She went to the spring and drew some water. I asked her to please let me have a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: She quickly lowered her jug from her shoulder and told me, ‘Have a drink while I also water your camels.’ So I drank, and she also gave my camels water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That’s when I asked, ‘Whose daughter are you?’
“She replied, ‘I’m the daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milcah bore for him.’
“So I gave her a ring for her nose and bracelets for her wrists.
speaker: Narrator

text: I bowed down and worshipped the Lord, and I praised the Lord God of my master Abraham, who led me on the true way to request the daughter of my master’s brother for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, if you wish to show gracious love and truth toward my master, tell me so. But if not, tell me, so that I may go elsewhere.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Since this has come from the Lord,” Laban and Bethuel both replied, “we cannot speak one way or another.
speaker: Narrator

text: So here’s Rebekah—she’s right in front of you. Take her and go, so she can become a wife for your master’s son, just as the Lord has decreed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham’s servant heard what they had said, he bowed down to the ground before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant brought out some silver and gold items, along with some clothing, and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave gifts to her brother and to her mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He and the men with him ate and drank, and then they spent the night.
When they got up the next morning, the servant requested, “Send me off to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But her brother and mother said, “Let the young lady stay with us a few days—at least ten—and after that she may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please don’t delay me,” the servant answered them. “The Lord has made my journey successful. Send me off so I can return to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “We’ll call the young lady and see what she has to say about this.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they called Rebekah and asked her, “Do you want to go with this man?”
“I will go,” she replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent off their sister Rebekah, along with her personal assistant, Abraham’s servant, and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As they were leaving, they all blessed Rebekah by saying,
“Our sister, may you become the mother of tens of millions!
    May your descendants take over
        the city gates of those who hate them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah and her young servant women got up, mounted their camels, and followed Abraham’s servant, who took Rebekah and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, as Isaac was returning one evening from Beer-lahai-roi (he had been living in the Negev),
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac went out walking in a field. He looked up, and all of a sudden there were some camels coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah looked up, and when she saw Isaac, she quickly dismounted from her camel
speaker: Narrator

text:
and asked the servant, “Who is that man coming in the field to meet us?”
“That’s my master,” the servant told her. So she reached for a veil and covered herself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant informed Isaac about everything he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Isaac brought Rebekah into the tent that had belonged to his mother Sarah and married her. Isaac loved her, and that’s how he was comforted following the loss of his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham had taken another wife whose name was Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. Dedan’s sons were the Asshurites, Letushites, and Leummites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Midian’s sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All of these were Keturah’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave everything he owned to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still alive, Abraham gave gifts to his concubines and sent them to the east country in order to keep them away from his son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham lived for 175 years,
speaker: Narrator

text: then passed away, dying at a ripe old age, having lived a full life, and joined his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah near Mamre, in the field that used to belong to Zohar the Hittite’s son Ephron.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the same field that Abraham had bought from the Hittites, where Abraham and his wife Sarah were buried.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac, who continued to live near Beer-lahai-roi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is what happened to Ishmael, whom Sarah’s Egyptian servant Hagar bore for Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s a list of the names of Ishmael’s sons, recorded by their names and descendants: Nebaioth was the firstborn, followed by Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Ishmael’s children, listed by their names according to their villages and their camps. There were a total of twelve tribal chiefs, according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael lived for 137 years, then he took his last breath, died, and joined his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: His descendants settled from Havilah to Shur (that’s near Egypt), all the way to Assyria, in defiance of all of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of Isaac, Abraham’s son. Abraham fathered Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel, the Aramean from Paddan-aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Isaac prayed to the Lord on behalf of his wife, since she was unable to conceive children, and the Lord responded to him—his wife Rebekah became pregnant.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the infants kept on wrestling each other inside her womb, she asked herself, “Why is this happening?” So she asked the Lord for an explanation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Two nations are in your womb,” the Lord responded, “and two separate people will emerge. One people will be the stronger, and the older one will serve the younger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sure enough, when her due date arrived, she delivered twin sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first son came out reddish—his entire body was covered with hair—so they named him Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, his brother came out with his hand clutching Esau’s heel, so they named him Jacob. Isaac was 60 years old when they were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the boys were growing up, Esau became skilled at hunting and was a man of the outdoors, but Jacob was the quiet type who tended to stay indoors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac loved Esau, because he loved to hunt, while Rebekah loved Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day, while Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau happened to come in from being outdoors, and he was feeling famished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau told Jacob, “Let me gobble down some of this red stuff, since I’m starving.” (That’s how Esau got his nickname “Edom”.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob responded, “Sell me your birthright. Do it now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look! I’m about to die,” Esau replied. “What good is this birthright to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob insisted, “Swear it by an oath right now.” So he swore an oath to him and sold his birthright to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob gave Esau some of his food, along with some boiled stew. So Esau ate, drank, got up, and left, after having belittled his own birthright.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, a famine swept through the land. This famine was different from the previous famine that had occurred earlier, during Abraham’s lifetime. So Isaac went to Abimelech, king of the Philistines, at Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s when the Lord appeared to Isaac. “You are not to go down to Egypt,” he said. “Instead, you are to settle down in an area within this land where I’ll tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remain in this land, and I’ll be with and bless you by giving all these lands to you and to your descendants in fulfillment of my solemn promise that I made to your father Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll cause you to have as many descendants as the stars of the heavens, and I’ll certainly give all these lands to your descendants. Later on, through your descendants all the nations of the earth will bless one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to do this because Abraham did what I told him to do. He kept my instructions, commands, statutes, and laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac lived in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, the men of that place asked about his wife, so he replied, “She’s my sister,” because he was afraid to call her “my wife.” He kept thinking, “…otherwise, the men around here will kill me on account of Rebekah, since she’s very beautiful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had been there awhile, Abimelech, king of the Philistines, looked out through a window and saw Isaac caressing his wife Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Abimelech called Isaac and confronted him. “She is definitely your wife!” he accused him, “So why did you claim, ‘She’s my sister?’”
Isaac responded, “Because I had thought ‘…otherwise, I’ll die on account of her.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What have you done to us?” Abimelech asked. “Any minute now, one of the people could have had sex with your wife and you would have caused all of us to be guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he issued this order to everyone: “Whoever touches this man or his wife is to be executed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac received a 100-fold return on what he planted that year in the land he received, because the Lord blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He became very wealthy and lived a life of wealth, becoming more and more wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He owned so many sheep, cattle, and servants that the Philistines eventually became envious of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They filled in with sand all of the wells that Isaac’s father Abraham’s servants had dug during his lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech ordered Isaac, “Move away from us! You’ve become more powerful than we are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac moved from there and encamped in the Gerar Valley, where he settled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac re-excavated some wells that his father had first dug during his lifetime, because the Philistines had filled them with sand after Abraham’s death. Isaac renamed those wells with the same names that his father had called them.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Isaac’s servants were digging in the valley, they discovered a well with flowing water.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the herdsmen who lived in Gerar quarreled with Isaac’s herdsmen. “The water is ours,” they said. As a result, Isaac named the well Esek, for they had fiercely disputed with him about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his workers started digging another well, those herdsmen quarreled about that one, too, so Isaac named it Sitnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he left that area and dug still another well. Because they did not quarrel over that one, Isaac named it Rehoboth, because he used to say, “The Lord has enlarged the territory for us. We will prosper in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, he left there and went to Beer-sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: where one night the Lord appeared to him. “I am the God of your father Abraham,” he told him. “Don’t be afraid, because I’m with you. I’m going to bless you and multiply your descendants on account of my servant Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, Isaac built an altar there and called on the name of the Lord. He also pitched his tents there and his servants dug a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Abimelech traveled from Gerar to visit Isaac. He arrived with Ahuzzath, his staff advisor, and Phicol, the commanding officer of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why have you come to see me,” Isaac asked them, “since you hate me so much that you sent me away from you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We’ve seen that the Lord is with you,” they responded, “so we’re proposing an agreement between us—between us and you. Allow us to make a treaty with you
speaker: Narrator

text: by which you’ll agree not to do us any harm, just as we haven’t harmed you, since we’ve done nothing but good for you after we sent you away in peace. As a result, you’ve been tremendously blessed by the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac held a festival for them, and they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: They woke up early the next morning and made the treaty. After this, Isaac sent them off and they left on peaceful terms.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very same day, Isaac’s servants arrived and reported to him about a well that they had just completed digging. “We’ve found water!” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac named the well Shebah, which is why the city is named Beer-sheba to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau was 40 years old, he married Judith, the daughter of Beeri the Hittite and Basemath, the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: This brought extreme grief to Isaac and Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Isaac grew so old that he could not see. One day, he called his eldest son Esau. “My son,” he called out to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look how old I am! I could die any day now,
speaker: Narrator

text: so go find your weapons, take your bow and arrows, go outside, and hunt some game for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then prepare some food, just the way I like it, and bring it to me so that I can eat and bless you before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rebekah overheard Isaac while he was speaking to his son Esau. When Esau had gone out to the field to hunt and bring in some game,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah gave these instructions to her son Jacob: “Quick! Pay attention!” she said. “I heard your father talking to your brother Esau. He told him,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Bring me some game and then prepare some food for me so I can eat and bless you in the presence of the Lord before I die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, my son, listen to what I have to say and pay attention to what I’m about to tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the flock and bring me two healthy young goats. I’ll prepare some delicious food for your father, just the way he loves it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to take it to your father so that he can eat and bless you before he dies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But look!” Jacob pointed out to his mother Rebekah, “My brother Esau is a hairy man, but I’m smooth skinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: My father might touch me and he’ll realize that I’m deceiving him. Then, I’ll bring a curse on myself instead of a blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “My son,” she replied, “let any curse against you fall on me. Just listen to me, then go and get them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So out he went, got them, and brought them to his mother, who then prepared some delicious food, just the way his father liked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah took some garments that belonged to her elder son Esau—the best ones available—and put them on her younger son Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She put some goat skins over his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she handed the delicious food and bread that she had prepared to her son Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who went to his father and said, “My father…”
“It’s me!” he replied. “Which one are you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m Esau, your firstborn!” Jacob told his father. “I’ve done what you asked, so please sit up and eat what I caught, so you can bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How did you get it so quickly, my son?” Isaac asked.
Jacob responded, “…because the Lord your God made me successful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac told Jacob, “Come here, my son, so I can feel you and know for sure whether or not you’re my son Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob approached his father, who felt him and said, “It’s Jacob’s voice, but Esau’s hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He didn’t recognize Jacob, because his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau, so Isaac blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked, “Are you really my son Esau?”
“I am,” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come closer to me,” Isaac replied, “so I can eat some of the game, my son, and then bless you.” So Jacob came closer, and Isaac ate. Jacob also brought wine so his father could drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jacob’s father Isaac told him, “Come closer and kiss me, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Jacob drew closer to kiss him. When Isaac smelled the scent of his son’s clothes, he blessed him and said,
“How my son’s scent is the fragrance of the field
    that the Lord has blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the Lord grant you dew from the skies,
    and from the fertile land;
may he grant you
    abundant grain and fresh wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Just after Isaac had finished blessing Jacob and Jacob had left his father Isaac, Jacob’s brother Esau returned from hunting,
speaker: Narrator

text: prepared some delicious food, brought it to his father, and told him, “Can you get up now, father, so you may eat some of your son’s game and then bless me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his father Isaac asked him, “Who are you?”
“I’m Esau, your firstborn son,” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Isaac began to tremble violently. “Who then,” he asked, “hunted some game and brought it to me to eat before you arrived, so that I’ve blessed him? Indeed, he is blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau realized what his father Isaac was saying, he began to wail out loud bitterly. “Bless me,” he cried, “even me, too, my father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac replied, “Your brother came here deceitfully and stole your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Isn’t his name rightly called Jacob?” Esau asked. “He has circumvented me this second time. First, he took away my birthright, and now, look how he also stole my blessing.” Then he added, “Haven’t you reserved a blessing for me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, Isaac told Esau, “Look! I’ve predicted that he’s going to become your master, and I’ve assigned all his brothers to be his servants. What then can I do for you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau implored his father, “Don’t you have even one blessing for me, my father? Bless me, even me too, my father!” Then Esau lifted his voice and wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
By your sword you’ll live;
    but you’ll serve your brother.
But when you’ve become restless,
    you’ll break off his yoke from your neck.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau harbored animosity toward Jacob because of the way his father had blessed him. Esau kept saying to himself, “The time to mourn for my father is very near. That’s when I’m going to kill my brother Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, what Rebekah’s older son Esau had been saying was reported to her, so she sent for her younger son Jacob and warned him, “Look! Your brother is planning to get even by killing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son, you’d better do what I say! Get up, run off to my brother Laban in Haran,
speaker: Narrator

text: and stay there with him a few days until your brother’s fury subsides.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that happens and he has forgotten what you’ve done to him, I’ll send for you so you can return from there. Why should I be bereaved of you both in one day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah also told herself, “Heth’s daughters are making me tired of living. If Jacob marries one of Heth’s daughters, and she turns out to be just like these other local women, what kind of life would there be left for me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Isaac called Jacob and blessed him, instructing him, “Don’t marry a wife from the local Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, get up, travel to Paddan-aram, and visit the household of Bethuel, your mother’s father. Marry one of Laban’s daughters, since he’s your mother’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful so that your descendants become a whole group of people.
speaker: Narrator

text: May he give you and your descendants the blessings that he gave Abraham. May you possess the land where you have lived that God gave to Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac sent Jacob off toward Paddan-aram to visit Bethuel’s son Laban, the Aramean and brother of Rebekah, the mother of Jacob and Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau noticed that after Isaac had blessed Jacob as he was sending him off to Paddan-aram to marry a wife from there, he had instructed Jacob, “Don’t marry a Canaanite woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jacob had obeyed his father and mother’s instructions to set out for Paddan-aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau realized that Canaan women didn’t please his father Isaac,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he went to Abraham’s son Ishmael and married Ishmael’s daughter Mahalath, who was the sister of Nebaioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Jacob had left Beer-sheba and was on his way to Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reached a certain place and spent the night there, because the sun was setting. He found a stone there, used it for a pillow, and slept there for the night,
speaker: Narrator

text: when he had a dream! He saw a raised highway that had been built with its ending point on earth and its beginning point in heaven. God’s angels were ascending and descending on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was the Lord, standing above it and telling Jacob, “I am the Lord God of your grandfather Abraham. I’m Isaac’s God, too. I’m giving you and your descendants the ground on which you’re sleeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your descendants are going to become like the dust of the earth and spread out to the west, east, north, and south. All the families of the earth will be blessed through you and your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now pay attention! I’m here with you, and I’m going to be watching over you wherever you go. I’m going to bring you back to this land, because I won’t ever leave you until I’ve accomplished what I’ve promised about you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob woke up during the night and told himself, “Surely, the Lord is in this place and I never knew it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: In mounting terror, he cried out, “How scary this place is! This is nothing less than God’s house and the gateway to heaven!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob got up early the next morning, he took the stone that he had used for his pillow, set it up as a pillar, drenched it with oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and named the place Beth-el, although previously the city had been named Luz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made this solemn vow: “If God remains with me, watches over me throughout this journey that I’m taking, gives me food to eat and clothes to wear,
speaker: Narrator

text: and returns me safely to my father’s house, then the Lord will be my God,
speaker: Narrator

text: this stone that I’ve erected in the form of a pillar will be God’s house, and I’ll give you a tenth of everything that you give to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob journeyed on and reached the territory that belonged to the people who lived in the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was observing a well that had been dug out on the open range, all of a sudden he noticed three flocks of sheep lying there, because shepherds watered their flocks from that well. There was a very large stone that covered the opening of the well,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when all the flocks had been gathered there, they would roll away the stone from the opening of the well, water their flocks, and then return the stone to its place covering the opening of the well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob asked them, “My brothers, where are you from?”
“We’re from Haran,” they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you happen to know Nahor’s son Laban?” he inquired.
“We do,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he asked them, “How’s he doing?”
“Very well,” they answered. “As a matter of fact, look over there! That’s his daughter Rachel, coming here with his sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” Jacob replied. “The sun is still high. It’s not yet time for the flocks to be gathered. Let’s water the sheep, then let them graze.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they responded, “We can’t do that until all the sheep have been gathered and the stone has been rolled away from the opening of the well. Only then can we water the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still talking with them, Rachel arrived with her father’s sheep, since she was a shepherdess.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban, his mother’s brother, accompanied by Laban’s sheep, Jacob approached the well, rolled the stone from the opening of the well, and then watered his mother’s brother Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and began to cry out loud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob told Rachel that he was related to her father, since he was Rebekah’s son, so she ran and told her father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Laban heard the news about his sister’s son Jacob, he ran out to meet him. He embraced him, kissed him, and brought him back to his house. Then Jacob told Laban about everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban responded, “You certainly are my flesh and blood!” So Jacob stayed with him for about a month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Laban asked Jacob, “Should you serve me for free, just because you’re my nephew? Let’s talk about what your wages should be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban happened to have two daughters. The older one was named Leah and the younger was named Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah looked rather plain, but Rachel was lovely in form and appearance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob loved Rachel, so he made this offer to Laban: “I’ll serve you for seven years for Rachel, your younger daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s better that I give her to you than to another man,” Laban replied, “so stay with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob served seven years for Rachel, but it seemed like only a few days because of his love for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Jacob told Laban, “Bring me my wife, now that my time of service has been completed, so I can go be with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban gathered all the men who lived in that place and held a wedding festival.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night Laban took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob. He had marital relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban also gave his servant woman Zilpah to Leah to be her maidservant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning, Jacob realized that it was Leah! “What have you done to me?” he demanded of Laban. “Didn’t I serve you for seven years in order to marry Rachel? Why did you deceive me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Laban responded, “It’s not the practice of our place to give the younger one in marriage before the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fulfill the week for this daughter, then we’ll give you the other one in exchange for serving me another seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob completed another seven years’ work, and then Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban also gave his woman servant Bilhah to his daughter Rachel to be her maidservant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob also married Rachel, since he loved her. He served Laban another full seven years’ work for Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the Lord noticed that Leah was being neglected, so he made her fertile, while Rachel remained childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah conceived, bore a son, and named him Reuben, because she was saying, “The Lord had looked on my torture, so now my husband will love me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, she conceived again, bore a son, and declared, “Because the Lord heard that I’m neglected, he gave me this one, too.” So she named him Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, she conceived again and said, “This time my husband will become attached to me, now that I’ve borne him three sons.” So he named him Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she conceived yet again, bore a son, and said, “This time I’ll praise the Lord.” So she named him Judah.
Then she stopped bearing children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel noticed that she was not bearing children for Jacob, so because she envied her sister Leah, she told Jacob, “If you don’t give me sons, I’m going to die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: That made Jacob angry with Rachel, so he asked her, “Can I take God’s place, who has not allowed you to conceive?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel responded, “Here’s my handmaid Bilhah. Go have sex with her. She can bear children on my knees so I can have children through her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel gave Jacob her woman servant Bilhah to be his wife, and Jacob had sex with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah conceived and bore a son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel said, “God has vindicated me! He has heard my voice and has given me a son.” Therefore, she named him Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel’s servant conceived again and bore a second son for Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Rachel said, “I’ve been through a mighty struggle with my sister and won.” She named him Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Leah saw that she had stopped bearing children, she took her woman servant Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s servant Zilpah bore a son to Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Leah exclaimed, “How fortunate!” So she named him Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Leah’s servant Zilpah bore a second son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “How happy I am, because women will call me happy!” So she named him Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, during the wheat harvest season, Reuben went out and found some mandrakes in the field and brought them back for his mother Leah. Then Rachel told Leah, “Please give me your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
In response, Leah asked her, “Wasn’t it enough that you’ve taken away my husband? Now you also want to take my son’s mandrakes!”
But Rachel replied, “Very well, let’s let Jacob sleep with you tonight in exchange for your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob came in from the field that evening, Leah went to meet him and told him, “You’re having sex with me tonight. I traded my son’s mandrakes for you!” So he slept with her that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard what Leah had said, so she conceived and bore a fifth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “God has paid me for giving my servant to my husband as his wife.” So she named him Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Leah conceived again and bore a sixth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “God has given me a good gift. This time my husband will exalt me, because I’ve borne him six sons.” So she named him Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, Leah conceived, bore a daughter, and named her Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God remembered Rachel. He listened to her and opened her womb,
speaker: Narrator

text: so she conceived, bore a son, and remarked, “God has removed my shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Because she had been asking, “May God give me another son,” she named him Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob told Laban, “Send me off so that I can go back to my place and country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me my wives and children for whom I’ve served you. Then I’ll leave, since you’re aware of my service to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban responded, “If I’ve found favor in your sight, please stay with me, because I’ve learned through divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Name your wage, and I’ll give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob replied to Laban, “You know how I’ve served you and how your cattle thrived under my care.
speaker: Narrator

text: What you had previously was only a few head, but the herd has now multiplied, because the Lord has blessed you through my efforts. But now, when am I going to be able to provide for my own household?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do I have to give you?” Laban asked.
Jacob responded, “You don’t have to give me anything. Just do this for me: Let me tend your flock again and watch over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me walk among your flocks today and remove every speckled or spotted sheep, along with every black lamb, and let me do the same with the speckled and spotted goats. These will be my wages.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the future, you’ll be able to verify my honesty because, when you come to check what I’ve earned, if you find a goat that’s not speckled or spotted or a sheep that’s not black, then it will have been stolen by me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Very well,” Laban replied. “We’ll do it the way you’ve asked.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day, Laban removed the male goats that were striped or spotted, all the female goats that were speckled or spotted—that is, every one that had white on them—and all the black lambs and placed them into the care of his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent them as far away from Jacob as a three days’ journey could take them.
Meanwhile, Jacob kept tending the rest of Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob took branches from white poplar trees, freshly cut almond trees, and some other trees, stripped off their bark to make white streaks, and uncovered the white part inside the branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed the branches that he had stripped bare in all the watering troughs where the flocks came to drink. He placed the branches in front of the flock, and they went into heat as they came to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the flocks mated in front of the branches, they would bear offspring that were striped, speckled, or spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob kept the lambs separate, facing the striped and entirely black ones that belonged to Laban’s flock. He set his own herd by itself and would not let them be with Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the more vigorous of the flock came into heat, Jacob would place the branches in the troughs in front of the flock to make them mate by the branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he didn’t put the branches in front of any of the feeble members of the flock. As a result, the feeble ones belonged to Laban, but the stronger ones belonged to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the man Jacob prospered so much that he had large flocks, female and male servants, as well as camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob used to listen while Laban’s sons kept on complaining, “Jacob has taken over everything our father owns! He made himself wealthy from what belongs to our father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob also noticed that the way Laban had been looking at him wasn’t as nice as it had been just two days earlier.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord ordered Jacob, “Go back to your father’s territory and to your relatives. I’ll be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah to come out to the field where his flock was
speaker: Narrator

text: and informed them, “I’ve noticed that the way your father has been looking at us hasn’t been as nice as it was just two days ago. But my father’s God has been with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know I’ve been serving your father with all my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, your father has cheated me. He broke our wage agreement ten times. However, God didn’t allow him to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Laban said, ‘The speckled ones will be your wages,’ then all the flock gave birth to speckled ones. Then when he said, ‘The streaked ones will be your wages,’ all the flock gave birth to streaked offspring.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So God has taken away your father’s livestock and has given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was, when it was time for the livestock to breed, I once looked up in a dream, and the male goats that were mating with the flock were producing streaked, speckled, and spotted offspring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Later, the angel of God spoke to me in a dream, ‘Jacob.’
“‘Here I am,’ I replied
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Look around!’ he said. ‘Go ahead, look! All the male goats have been mating with the flock, producing offspring that are streaked, speckled, and spotted, because I’ve been watching everything that Laban has done to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the God of Bethel, the place where you consecrated that stone and made a vow to me. Now get up, leave this territory, and return to your native land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel and Leah asked him, “Do we have anything left of inheritance remaining in our father’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: He’s treating us like foreigners. He sold us and spent all of the money that rightfully belonged to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, all of the wealth that God has stripped away from our father belongs to us now and to our children. So do everything that God tells you to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob got up, seated his children and wives on camels,
speaker: Narrator

text: and drove all his livestock ahead of him, with everything that belonged to him, including the livestock that he had bought and accumulated in Paddan-aram, intending to deliver them to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Laban had been out shearing his sheep. While he was away, Rachel stole her father’s personal idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Jacob had deceived Laban the Aramean, because he had never told him that he was intending to leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob fled, taking everything that he owned. He got up, crossed the river, and headed to the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, somebody reported to Laban that Jacob had left,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he took his relatives with him and pursued Jacob. Laban was on the road for seven days when he finally caught up with Jacob in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night, God appeared to Laban the Aramean in a dream and warned him, “Be careful what you say to Jacob, whether it’s one word good or bad.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Jacob had pitched his tent on the mountain, where Laban had caught up with him. Laban and his relatives encamped on that same mountain in the hill country of Gilead, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban asked Jacob, “What did you do? You deceived me, carried off my daughters like you would war captives,
speaker: Narrator

text: ran away from me secretly, and stole from me by not keeping me informed. Otherwise, I could have sent you off with a party and singing, accompanied by a band playing tambourines and harps.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is, you didn’t even allow me to kiss my grandchildren and daughters goodbye! You’ve acted foolishly.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s actually in my power to do some serious evil to you, but last night the God of your father told me, ‘Be careful what you say to Jacob whether good or evil.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, you can go if you must go, because you certainly are longing to go to your father’s house. But why did you steal my gods?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I was afraid,” Jacob replied. “I thought you might take your daughters from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to your gods, if you find someone has them in their possession, he’s a dead man. Take our relatives as witnesses, search through our belongings, and take whatever belongs to you that’s in my possession.” But Jacob didn’t know that Rachel had stolen the idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban entered Jacob’s tent, Leah’s tent, and the tents of the two maid servants, but he didn’t find them. Then he left Leah’s tent and entered Rachel’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Rachel had taken the idols, placed them inside the saddle of her camel, and sat on them. Laban searched through the whole tent, but found nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel told her father, “Sir, please don’t be angry that I cannot stand up in your presence. It’s that time of the month.” So Laban searched for the idols, but never did find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob got angry and started an argument with Laban. “What have I done?” he demanded. “What’s my crime that would cause you to come pursue me so violently?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that you’ve searched all my belongings, what did you find that belongs to your house? Set it here in front of our relatives and we’ll let them judge between us!
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, these past 20 years that I’ve been with you, your sheep and goats never had miscarriages, I never once ate any of the rams from your flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whatever was torn by beasts, I never bothered to bring to you. Instead, I bore the losses myself. Even so, you demanded that I provide restitution for anything that was stolen, whether during the day or the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was, I was attacked by drought during the day and by cold at night. I never got any decent rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve lived in your house these 20 years—serving fourteen years for your two daughters and another six years for your flocks. During all that time you changed my wages ten times.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the God of my father—the God of Abraham, the God whom Isaac feared—had not been with me, you would have sent me away empty handed. But God saw my misery and how hard I’ve worked with my own hands—and he rebuked you last night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Laban answered Jacob, “These women are my daughters. These children are my children. The flocks are mine. In fact, everything that you see belongs to me. But what would I do today to my daughters and the children they have borne?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let’s make a covenant just between you and me. And let it serve as a witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took a stone and raised it as a pillar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob told his relatives, “Go gather some stones.” So they picked up stones and stacked them one on top of the other. Then they had a meal together there by the stack of stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban named the place Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob named it Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said, “This stack will serve as a witness between you and me today.” That’s how the place came to be named Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was also called Mizpah, because Laban said, “May the Lord watch between you and me, when we are estranged from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you mistreat my daughters or if you take other wives besides them, though no one is watching us, keep in mind that God stands as a witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” Laban added, “Here is the stack of stones and here is the pillar that I’ve set up between you and me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This stack is a witness, and so is this pillar, reminding me not to cross beyond this stack of stones, and reminding you not to pass by this stack in my direction, intending to cause harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May Abraham’s God and Nahor’s god judge between us.”
So Jacob made an oath by his father’s Fear,
speaker: Narrator

text: offered sacrifices there on the mountain, and called on his relatives to eat some food. So they ate the food and spent the night on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning, Laban woke up, kissed his grandchildren and daughters, blessed them, and then left for home.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jacob went on his way, angels from God met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was watching them, Jacob said, “This must be God’s camp,” so he named that place Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob sent messengers ahead of him into the land of Seir (that is, into the territory of Edom) to meet his brother Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: He instructed them, “This is what you are to say to my master Esau: ‘Your servant Jacob told me to tell you, “I’ve journeyed to stay with Laban and I’ve remained there until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: I now have cattle, donkeys, flocks, and male and female servants. I’m sending this message to you, sir, so that you’ll show favor to me.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the messengers returned to Jacob and reported, “We went to your brother Esau. He’s now coming to meet you—and he has 400 men with him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Feeling mounting terror and distress, Jacob divided the people who were with him into two groups, doing the same with the flocks, the cattle, and the camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was thinking, “If Esau comes to one group and attacks it, then the remaining group may escape.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob prayed, “O God of my father Abraham, O God of my father Isaac, O Lord, you who told me, ‘Return to your country and to your relatives and I’ll cause things to go well for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m unworthy of all your gracious love, your faithfulness, and everything that you’ve done for your servant. When I first crossed over this river, I had only my staff. But now I’ve become two groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deliver me from my brother Esau’s control, because I’m terrified of him, and I’m afraid that he’s coming to attack me, the mothers, and their children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, you promised me that ‘I’m certainly going to cause things to go well with you, and I’m going to make your offspring as numerous as the sand of the sea, which cannot be counted.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob spent the night there. Out of everything that he had brought with him, he chose a gift for his brother Esau—
speaker: Narrator

text: 200 female goats, 20 male goats, 200 ewes, 20 rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: 30 milking camels with their young, 40 cows with ten bulls, and 20 female donkeys with ten male donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He entrusted them into the care of his servants, one herd at a time. Then he told his servants, “Go in front of me, making sure there’s plenty of space between herds.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To the first group he said, “When you meet my brother Esau, if he asks, ‘To whom do you belong? Where are you going? And to whom do these herds belong?’
speaker: Narrator

text: then you are to reply, ‘We’re from your servant Jacob. The herds are a gift. He’s sending them to my master, Esau. Look! There he is, coming along behind us.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He issued similar instructions to the second and third group, as well as to all the others who drove the herds that followed: “This is how you are to speak to Esau when you find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are to tell him, ‘Look! Your servant Jacob is coming along behind us.’”
Jacob was thinking, “I’ll pacify him with the presents that are being sent ahead of me. Then, when I meet him, perhaps he’ll accept me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the presents went ahead of him, while he spent that night in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later that night, he woke up, quickly took his two wives, his two women servants, and his eleven children, and forded the river at Jabbok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took them across the river, along with all his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so Jacob was left alone, and he struggled with a man until daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man realized that he hadn’t yet won the struggle, he injured the socket of Jacob’s thigh, dislocating it as he wrestled with him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, “Let me go, because the dawn has come.”
“I won’t let you go,” Jacob replied, “unless you bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the man asked him, “What’s your name?”
“Jacob,” he responded
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your name won’t be Jacob anymore,” the man replied, “but Israel, because you exerted yourself against both God and men, and you’ve emerged victorious.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please,” Jacob inquired, “Tell me your name.”
But he asked, “Why are you asking about my name?” And he blessed Jacob there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob would later call that place Peniel, because “I saw God face to face, but my life was spared.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun was rising above Jacob as he crossed over from Peniel, limping due to his wounded thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, to this day the Israelis do not eat the hip tendon that connects to the thigh socket, because he had injured the socket of the thigh where the tendon connected to Jacob’s hip.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob looked off in the distance, there was Esau coming toward him, accompanied by 400 men! So Jacob divided Leah’s children, Rachel, and the children of the two servants into separate groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he positioned the women servants and their children first, then Leah and her children next, and then Rachel and Joseph after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went out to meet Esau, passing in front of all of them, and bowed low to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau ran to meet Jacob and embraced him. Then he fell on his neck and kissed him. And they wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Esau eventually looked around, he saw the women and the children. “Who are these people with you?” he asked.
“The children, whom God has graciously given your servant,” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the women servants approached, accompanied by their children, and bowed low.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah also approached, and she and her children bowed low. After this, Joseph and Rachel approached and bowed low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Esau asked, “What are all these livestock for?”
“To solicit favor from you, sir,” Jacob answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau replied, “I already have so much, my brother, so keep what belongs to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please,” Jacob implored him, “don’t refuse. If I’m to receive favor from you, then receive this gift from me, because seeing your face is like seeing the face of God, since you have favorably accepted me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So receive my blessing, which has been sent to you, since God has been gracious to me. Besides, I have enough.” Because Jacob kept pressing him, Esau accepted the gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau suggested, “Let’s set out and travel together, but let me go in front of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sir, you know that the children are frail,” Jacob suggested, “and the ewes and cows with me are still nursing their young. If they’re driven even for a day, the entire flock will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: So allow yourself to go ahead of your servant while I travel more slowly, letting the herds set their own pace with the children until I arrive to see my lord in Seir.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Esau said, “Let me leave with you some of the people who are with me.”
“Why do that?” Jacob asked. “I’ve already found favor in your sight, sir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau set out that very day back on his way to Seir,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Jacob set out for Succoth, built a house there, and constructed some cattle shelters. He named the place Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jacob had arrived safely from Paddan-aram, he entered the city of Shechem, which was located in the territory of Canaan, and encamped facing that city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he bought a parcel of land for 100 pieces of silver from the descendants of Hamor, Shechem’s father. He pitched his tent there,
speaker: Narrator

text: set up an altar, and named it El-elohe-israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Dinah, Leah’s daughter whom she had borne to Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hamor the Hivite’s son Shechem, the regional leader, saw her, he grabbed her and raped her, humiliating her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was attached to Dinah, Jacob’s daughter, since he loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shechem told his father Hamor, “Get this young woman for me to be my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Jacob learned that Shechem had dishonored his daughter Dinah while his sons were still out with their cattle on the open range, he remained silent until they returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Shechem’s father Hamor arrived to talk to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then Jacob’s sons arrived from the field. When they heard what had happened, they were distraught with grief and livid with anger toward Shechem, because he had committed a disgraceful deed in Israel by forcing Jacob’s daughter to have sex, an act that never should have happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hamor said this: “My son is deeply attracted to your daughter. Please give her to him as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Intermarry with us. Give your daughters to us and take our sons for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live with us anywhere you want. Live, trade, and grow rich in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem also addressed Dinah’s father and brothers. He told them, “If you’ll just approve me, I’ll give whatever you ask of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: No matter how big or how extensive your demands are for a dowry and wedding presents from me, I’ll provide whatever you ask. Only give me the young lady to be my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob’s sons answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceptively, because Shechem had dishonored their sister Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told them, “We can’t do this. We can’t give our sister to a man who isn’t circumcised, because that would be insulting to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we’ll agree to your request, only if you will become like us by circumcising every male among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we’ll give our daughters to you and take your daughters for ourselves, live among you, and be as a united people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you won’t listen to us, then we’re going to take our daughter and leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What they said pleased Hamor and his son Shechem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so the young man did not delay the matter any further, since he was delighted with Jacob’s daughter.
Now Shechem was the most important person in his father’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hamor and his son Shechem entered the gate of their city and addressed the men of their city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These men are at peace with us,” they announced. “Therefore, let them live in the land and trade in it. Look! The land is large enough for them. Let’s take their daughters as wives for ourselves and let’s give our sons to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “However,” they added, “only on this condition will the men consent to live with us and be united as a single people with us: every male among us will have to be circumcised just as they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shouldn’t all their cattle, acquisitions, and animals belong to us? So, let’s give our consent to them, and then they’ll live with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the males who heard Hamor and his son Shechem, who had gone out to the city gate, were circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, while they were still in pain, Jacob’s sons Simeon and Levi, two of Dinah’s brothers, each grabbed a sword and entered the city unannounced, intending to kill all the males.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with their swords, took back Dinah from Shechem’s house, and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob’s other sons came along afterward and plundered the city where their sister had been defiled,
speaker: Narrator

text: seizing all of their flocks, herds, donkeys, and whatever else was in the city or had been left out in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: They carried off all their wealth, their children, and their wives as captives, plundering everything that remained in the houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob told Simeon and Levi, “You have certainly stirred up trouble for me! You’ve made me despised by the Canaanites and the Perizzites who live in this territory. Because I have only a few men with me, they’re going to gather themselves together and attack me until I am totally destroyed, along with my entire household!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Should he have treated our sister like a whore?” they asked in response.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, God told Jacob, “Get up, move to Bethel, and live there. Build an altar to the God who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob announced to his household and to everyone with him, “Throw away the foreign gods that you’ve kept among you, purify yourselves, and change your clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then let’s get up and go to Bethel, where I’ll build an altar to the God who answered me when I was in distress and who was with me on the road, wherever I went.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they handed over to Jacob all their foreign gods on which they had been depending, along with the rings that they were wearing on their ears. Jacob buried them under the oak that grew near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they set out on their journey, because the people who lived in the cities around them feared God, they did not pursue Jacob’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Jacob and everyone with him arrived at Luz (also called Beth-el) in the territory of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built an altar there to God and named the place El Beth-el, because God had revealed himself there when he was fleeing from his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah’s nurse Deborah died and was buried there, under the oak tree that was below Beth-el. That’s why the place was named Allon-bacuth.
speaker: Narrator

text: God appeared again to Jacob after he had arrived from Paddan-aram and blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then God told him,
“Your name is Jacob.
    No longer are you to be called Jacob.
        Instead, your name will be Israel.”
So God called his name Israel
speaker: Narrator

text:
and also told him,
“I am God Almighty.
    You are to be fruitful
        and multiply.
You will become a nation—
    in fact, an assembly of nations!
Kings will come from you—
    they’ll emerge from your own loins!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now as for the land
    that I gave to Abraham and Isaac,
I’m giving it to you
    and to your descendants who come after you.
I’m giving the land to you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, God ascended from the place where he had been speaking to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob erected a pillar of stone at that very place where God had spoken to him. He poured a drink offering over it, anointed it with oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and named the place where God had spoken to him Beth-el.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, they set out from Beth-el. While still a long way from Ephrathah, Rachel started to have trouble giving birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was suffering due to her difficult labor, the midwife told her, “Don’t fear! You’re going to have another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just before she died, Rachel called her son’s name Ben-oni, but his father Jacob named him Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrathah, also known as Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob erected a pillar over her grave, and that pillar stands over Rachel’s grave to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob continued his travels, and eventually pitched his tent facing Migdal Eder.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while Israel lived in that land, Reuben went inside his father’s tent and had sexual relations with his father’s concubine Bilhah, and Israel heard about it. Now Jacob had twelve sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s sons were Reuben (Jacob’s first-born), Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel’s sons were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel’s servant Bilhah’s sons were Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s servant Zilpah’s sons were Gad and Asher. These were Jacob’s sons who were born to him while he lived in Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob reached his father Isaac at Mamre, in Kiriath-arba (also known as Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac had lived a total of 180 years
speaker: Narrator

text: when he died and joined his ancestors at a ripe old age. Then his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a record of Esau’s genealogy, that is, of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau had married Canaanite women, including Elon the Hittite’s daughter Adah, Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah (who was Zibeon the Hivite’s daughter), and
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishamael’s daughter Basemath (who was Nebaioth’s sister).
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, Basemath bore Reuel, and
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were Esau’s sons, who were born to him in the territory of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Esau took his wives, his children, everyone in his household, his livestock, all his animals, and all his possessions that he had acquired in the territory of Canaan and moved far away from his brother Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text: because their holdings were too vast to allow them to stay together, since the land where they had settled was not able to support all of their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau lived in Mount Seir. (Esau was also known as Edom.)
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a record of the family history of Esau, the ancestor of the Edomites of Mount Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of Esau’s sons were Eliphaz (the son of Esau’s wife Adah) and Reuel (the son of Esau’s wife Basemath).
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliphaz’s sons were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timnah was a concubine of Esau’s son Eliphaz. She bore Amalek to Eliphaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuel’s sons were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, who was the daughter of Zibeon. She bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah for Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the tribal leaders of Esau’s descendants; that is, the children of Eliphaz, who was Esau’s firstborn: tribal leaders Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These were the tribal leaders who descended from Eliphaz in the territory of Edom. These were Adah’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Esau’s son Reuel: tribal leaders Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the tribal leaders who descended from Reuel in the territory of Edom. These were the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: tribal leaders Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These tribal leaders descended from Esau’s wife Oholibamah, Anah’s daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Esau (also known as Edom) and their tribal leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Seir the Horite, who lived in the territory: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the tribal leaders who descended from the Horites, the descendants of Seir in the territory of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lotan’s children were Hori and Hemam. Lotan’s sister was Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shobal’s children were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zibeon’s children were Aiah and Anah. Anah discovered the hot springs in the wilderness while grazing his father Zibeon’s donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anah’s children were Dishon and Anah’s daughter Oholibamah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon’s children were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezer’s children were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishan’s children were Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the tribal leaders who descended from the Horites: tribal leaders Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the tribal leaders who descended from the Horites, according to their tribal leaders in the territory of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a list of the kings who ruled the territory of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beor’s son Bela ruled over Edom. His city’s name was Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Bela died, Zerah’s son Jobab from Bozrah ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jobab died, Husham from the territory of the Temanites ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Husham died, Bedad’s son Hadad, who killed Midian in the field of Moab, ruled in his place. His city’s name was Avith.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth by the river ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Shaul died, Achbor’s son Baal-hanan ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Achbor’s son Baal-hanan died, Hadar ruled in his place. His city’s name was Pau. And his wife’s name was Mehetabel, who was the daughter of Matred, and granddaughter of Me-zahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the names of the chiefs who descended from Esau according to their clans, territories, and names: tribal leaders Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram. These were the chiefs who descended from Edom, according to their territories in their own land. This was the dynasty of Esau, who was the ancestor of the Edomites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob continued to live in the land they were occupying, where his father had journeyed in the territory of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
