This is a record of Jacob’s descendants.
When Joseph was seventeen years old, he was helping his brothers tend their flocks. He was a young man at that time, as were the children of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives. But Joseph would come back and tell his father that his brothers were doing bad things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his brothers, since he was born to him in his old age, so he had made a richly-embroidered tunic for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph’s brothers realized that their father loved him more than all of his brothers, they hated him so much that they were unable to speak politely to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about this time, Joseph had a dream and then told it to his brothers. As a result, his brothers hated him all the more!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let me tell you about this dream that I had!” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We were tying sheaves together out in the middle of the fields, when all of a sudden, my sheaf stood up erect! And then your sheaves gathered around it and bowed down to my sheaf!”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, his brothers replied, “Do you really think you’re going to rule us or lord it over us?” So they hated him even more because of his dreams and his interpretations of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then he had another dream, and he proceeded to tell his brothers about that one, too. “I had another dream,” he said. “The sun, moon, and eleven of the stars were bowing down before me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph told his father about this, his father rebuked him and asked him, “What kind of dream is that? Will I, your mother, and your brothers really come to you and bow down to the ground in front of you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, his brothers became more envious of him. But his father kept thinking about all of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, his brothers left to tend their father’s flock in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Israel instructed Joseph, “Your brothers are tending the flock in Shechem. Come here, because I’m going to send you to them.”
“Here I am!” he responded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go and see how things are with your brothers,” Israel ordered him. “And see how things are with the flock. Bring back a report for me.” Then he sent Joseph from the valley of Hebron.
When Joseph reached Shechem,
speaker: Narrator

text: a man found him wandering around in a field. So the man asked him, “What are you looking for?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m searching for my brothers,” he responded. “Tell me, where are they tending the flock?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “They’ve already left,” the man answered. “I heard them saying that they were headed to Dothan.” So Joseph followed his brothers to Dothan and found them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as soon as they saw him approaching from a distance, before he arrived they plotted together to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” they said. “Here comes the Dream Master!
speaker: Narrator

text: Come on! Let’s kill him and toss him into one of the cisterns. Then we’ll report that some wild animal devoured him and wait to see what becomes of his dreams!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reuben heard about it, he tried to save Joseph from their plot. “Let’s not do any killing,”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben told them. “And no blood shedding, either. Instead, let’s toss him into this cistern that’s way out here in the wilderness. But don’t lay a hand on him.” (Reuben intended to free Joseph and return him to his father.)
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was, when Joseph arrived where his brothers were, they stripped off the tunic that Jacob had given him—that is, the richly-embroidered tunic that he was wearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: They grabbed him and tossed him into the cistern, but the cistern was empty. (There was no water in it.)
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, while they were seated, eating their food, they looked around and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead with camels carrying spices, balm, and myrrh for sale down in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah suggested to his brothers, “Where’s the profit in just killing our brother and shedding his blood?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come on! Let’s sell him to the Ishmaelites! That way, we won’t have laid our hands on him. After all, he’s our brother, our own flesh.”
So Judah’s brothers listened to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Midianite merchants were passing through, they extracted Joseph from the cistern and sold Joseph for 20 pieces of silver to the Ishmaelites, who then took Joseph down to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, when Reuben returned to the cistern, Joseph wasn’t there! In mounting panic, he tore his clothes,
speaker: Narrator

text: returned to his brothers, and shouted, “He’s not there! Now what? Where am I to go?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took Joseph’s coat, slaughtered a young goat, and dipped the coat in the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they stretched out the richly-embroidered tunic to dry, and brought it to their father.
“We’ve found this,” they reported. “Look at it and see if this is or isn’t your son’s tunic.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Examining it, he cried out, “It’s my son’s tunic! A wild animal has no doubt torn Joseph to pieces.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob tore his clothes, dressed himself in sackcloth, and then mourned many days for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his sons and daughters showed up to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. He kept saying, “Leave me alone! I’ll go down to the next world, still mourning for my son.” So Joseph’s father wept for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, down in Egypt, the Midianites sold Joseph to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s court officials, who was also Commander-in-Chief of the imperial guards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, Judah left his brothers and went to live with an Adullamite man named Hirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Judah met the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua. He married her, had sexual relations with her,
speaker: Narrator

text: and she conceived, bore a son, and named him Er.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, she conceived again, bore another son, and named him Onan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she bore yet another son and named him Shelah. Judah was living in Kezib when she bore him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah found a wife for his oldest son Er. Her name was Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord considered Er, Judah’s oldest son, to be wicked—so he put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Judah instructed Onan, “You are to have sexual relations with your dead brother’s wife, performing the duty of a brother-in-law with her, and have offspring for your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Onan knew that the offspring wouldn’t be his own heir, so whenever he had sexual relations with his brother’s wife, he would spill his semen on the ground to avoid fathering offspring for his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord considered what Onan was doing to be evil, so he put him to death, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Judah told his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Go live as a widow in your father’s house until my son Shelah grows up.” But he was really thinking, “…otherwise, Shelah might die like his brothers.” So Tamar left and lived in her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some years later, Shua’s daughter (that is, Judah’s wife) died. As Judah was grieving, he visited the shearers of his flock in Timnah, accompanied by his Adullamite friend Hirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” somebody reported to Tamar, “Your father-in-law is going to Timnah to shear his sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she took off her mourning apparel, covered herself with a shawl, and concealed her outward appearance. Then she went out and sat at the entrance of Enaim, which is on the way to Timnah, because she knew that even though Shelah had grown up, she wasn’t being given to him as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, since she had concealed her face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So on the way, he turned aside, approached her, and said, “Come on! Let’s have some sex!” But he didn’t realize that he was talking to his own daughter-in-law.
“What will you give me,” she asked, “in order to have sex with me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll send you a young goat from the flock,” he responded.
But she pressed him, asking, “What security will you put up until you’ve sent it?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked, “What pledge do you want me to give you?”
“Your signet ring, cord, and the staff in your hand,” she suggested. So he gave them to her, had sex with her, and she became pregnant by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she got up and left. Later, she took off her shawl and put on her mourning clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, Judah sent his Adullamite friend to take her a young goat, intending to retrieve what he had put up as security from the woman, but he could not find her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked the men who lived in that area, “Where’s that temple prostitute who was sitting alongside the road at Enaim?”
But they replied, “There’s been no temple prostitute here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned to Judah and said, “I haven’t found her. Also, the men who are from there said, ‘There’s been no prostitute here.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said, “Let her have those things. Otherwise, we’ll become contemptible. I sent this young goat, but you didn’t find her.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three months later, it was reported to Judah, “Your daughter-in-law Tamar has turned to prostitution! And look! She’s pregnant because of it!”
“Bring her out,” Judah responded. “Let’s burn her to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were bringing her out, she sent this message to her father-in-law: “I am pregnant by the man to whom these things belong. Furthermore,” she added, “tell me to whom this signet ring, cord, and staff belongs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah recognized them, he admitted, “She is more upright than I, because I never did give her my son Shelah.” And he never had sex with her again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, when it was time for Tamar to give birth, she was carrying twins in her womb!
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was giving birth, one of them put out his hand, so the midwife grabbed it and tied something scarlet around his hand, observing, “This one came out first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was, he withdrew his hand, and then his brother was born. Amazed, the midwife cried out loud, “What’s this? A breach birth?” So that boy was named Perez.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, his brother came out, and around his hand was the scarlet. So they named him Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Joseph had been delivered to Egypt and turned over to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s court officials and the Commander-in-Chief of the imperial guards. An Egyptian, he bought Joseph from the Ishmaelites, who had brought him down there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was with Joseph. He became a very prosperous man while in the house of his Egyptian master,
speaker: Narrator

text: who could see that the Lord was with Joseph, because the Lord made everything prosper that Joseph did.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how Joseph pleased Potiphar as he served him. Eventually, Potiphar appointed Joseph as overseer of his entire household. Moreover, he entrusted everything that he owned into his care.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the time he appointed Joseph to be overseer over his entire household and everything that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The Lord’s blessing rested on Joseph, whether in Potiphar’s household or in Potiphar’s fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything that he owned, he entrusted into Joseph’s care. He never concerned himself about anything, except for the food he ate.
Now Joseph was well built and good looking.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why, sometime later, Joseph’s master’s wife looked straight at Joseph and propositioned him: “Come on! Let’s have a little sex!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused, telling his master’s wife, “Look! My master doesn’t have to worry about anything in the house with me in charge, and he has entrusted everything into my care.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one has more authority in this house than I do. He has withheld nothing from me, except you, and that’s because you’re his wife. So how can I commit such a horrible evil? How can I sin against God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She kept on talking to him like this day after day, but he wouldn’t listen to her. Not only would he refuse to have sex with her, he refused even to stay around her.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day, though, he went into the house to do his work. None of the household servants were inside,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so she grabbed Joseph by his outer garment and demanded “Let’s have some sex!”
Instead, Joseph ran outside, leaving his outer garment still in her hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she realized that he had left his outer garment right there in her hand, she ran outside
speaker: Narrator

text: and yelled for her household servants. “Look!” she cried out. “My husband brought in a Hebrew man to humiliate us. He came in here to have sex with me, but I screamed out loud!
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard me starting to scream, he left his outer garment with me and fled outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She kept his outer garment by her side until Joseph’s master came home,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then this is what she told him: “That Hebrew slave whom you brought to us came in here to rape me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I started to scream, he left his outer garment with me and ran outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph’s master heard his wife’s claim to the effect that “This is how your servant treated me,” he flew into a rage,
speaker: Narrator

text: arrested Joseph, and locked him up in the same prison where the king’s prisoners were confined. So Joseph remained there in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was with Joseph. He extended gracious love to him, causing the prison warden to be pleased with Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prison warden entrusted into Joseph’s care all the prisoners who were confined in prison. Whatever they did, Joseph was in charge of the work detail.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prison warden did not have to worry about anything under Joseph’s care, because the Lord was with him. That’s why Joseph prospered in everything he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, both the senior security advisor to the king of Egypt and his head chef offended their master, Egypt’s king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was so angry with his two officers—his senior security advisor and his head chef—
speaker: Narrator

text: that he locked them up in the prison dungeon operated by the captain of the guard, the very place where Joseph was imprisoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard entrusted them to Joseph’s custody, who took care of them, since they were to remain there in custody for a number of days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two of them each had a dream. They both had their dreams the same night, and there were separate interpretations for each dream—the senior security advisor and the head chef to the king of Egypt, who had confined them in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came to see them in the morning, he noticed how downcast they looked! They were both very sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he asked Pharaoh’s officers, who were with him in prison in his master’s house, “Why are you so sad today?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We had a dream,” they replied, “but there’s no one to interpret it.”
“Interpretations belong to God,” Joseph told them, “so please tell me your stories.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the senior security advisor related his dream to Joseph. “In my dream,” he said, “all of a sudden there was a vine in front of me!
speaker: Narrator

text: On the vine were three branches that budded. Blossoms shot out, and clusters grew up that produced ripe grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, with Pharaoh’s cup in my hand, I took the grapes, squeezed them into Pharaoh’s cup, then handed the cup directly to Pharaoh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph told him, “This is what your dream means: The three branches are three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three days, Pharaoh will encourage you and return you to your responsibilities. You’ll attend to Pharaoh’s personal wine cup, just as you did when you were his senior security advisor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But keep me in mind when things go well for you. Be sure to extend kindness to me by remembering me to Pharaoh. Bring me out of this prison,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews. Not only that, I haven’t done anything that deserves me being confined to this pit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the head chef heard that the interpretation was good, he told Joseph, “I was also in my dream. All of a sudden, there were three baskets with white bread stacked on top of my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was all kinds of food in the basket that was on top, including baked food for Pharaoh. The birds were eating them from the basket on my head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph replied, “This is what your dream means: The three baskets are also three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three more days, Pharaoh will behead you and hang you on gallows, where birds will eat your flesh from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, which just happened to be Pharaoh’s birthday, he threw a party for all his servants. He lifted the head of both his senior security advisor and of his head chef in front of his servants—
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, he restored his senior security advisor to his former responsibilities, including attending to Pharaoh’s personal wine cup,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he beheaded and hanged the head chef, just as Joseph had interpreted for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Despite all of this, the senior security advisor not only didn’t remember Joseph, he deliberately forgot him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two years later—to the day—Pharaoh dreamed that he was standing by the Nile River,
speaker: Narrator

text: when all of a sudden seven healthy, plump cows emerged from the Nile to graze in the grass that grew in the reeds that lined the bank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right after that, seven more cows came up out of the Nile. Ugly and gaunt, they stood next to the other cows on the bank of the Nile River.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all of a sudden they ate up the seven healthy, plump cows! Then Pharaoh woke up.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had fallen back to sleep, he had a second dream, in which seven ears of plump, fruit-filled grain grew up on a single stalk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly seven thin ears of grain that had been scorched by an east wind sprouted up right after them
speaker: Narrator

text: and ate up the seven plump, fruit-filled ears. Then Pharaoh woke up a second time, and it had been a very vivid dream!
speaker: Narrator

text: The very next morning, he was frustrated about the dream, so he sent word to summon all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them what he had dreamed, but no one could interpret them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh’s senior security advisor spoke up. “Maybe I should make a confession.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh was angry with some of his servants, he incarcerated me in custody of the captain of the bodyguard, along with Pharaoh’s head chef.
speaker: Narrator

text: We each had a dream on the same night, and each dream had its own meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There was a Hebrew young man incarcerated with us, who was also working as a servant to the captain of the bodyguard.
“We each related our dreams, and then he interpreted them for us. He provided specific meanings for each of our dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what he interpreted for each of us came true! Pharaoh restored me to my responsibilities, but he executed the other man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh sent word to summon Joseph quickly from the dungeon, so they shaved his beard, changed his clothes, and then sent him straight to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve had a dream,” Pharaoh told Joseph, “but nobody can interpret it. I’ve heard that you can interpret dreams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I can’t do that,” Joseph replied, “but God is concerned about Pharaoh’s well-being.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh told Joseph, “In my dream, I was standing on the bank of the Nile River,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all of a sudden seven healthy, plump, beautiful cows emerged from the Nile and began to graze among the reeds that line the bank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, seven other cows emerged after them, poor, ugly, and appearing very gaunt in their flesh. I’ve never seen anything as ugly as those cows anywhere in the entire land of Egypt!
speaker: Narrator

text: But those thin, gaunt cows gobbled up the first seven healthy cows!
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only that,” Pharaoh continued, “after they had finished devouring the cows, nobody could tell that they had gobbled them up, because they were just as ugly as before. Then I woke up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, I also dreamed about seven plump, fruit-filled ears of grain that grew up out of a single stalk.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of a sudden, seven thin, withered ears of grain, scorched by the east wind, sprouted up after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the thin ears gobbled up the seven good ears. I told all this to my advisors, but nobody was able to explain it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pharaoh’s dreams are identical,” Joseph replied. “God has told Pharaoh what he is getting ready to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven healthy cows represent seven years, as do the seven healthy ears. The dreams are identical.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven gaunt cows that arose after the healthy cows are seven years, as are the seven gaunt ears scorched by the east wind. There will be seven years of famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the message that I have for Pharaoh is that God is telling Pharaoh what he is getting ready to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be advised that seven years of phenomenal abundance are coming throughout all the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: but after them seven years of famine are ahead, during which all of the abundance will be forgotten throughout the land of Egypt. The famine will ravage the land so severely that
speaker: Narrator

text: there will be no surplus in the land due to the coming famine, because it will be very severe.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now since Pharaoh had that dream twice, it means that this event has been scheduled by God, and God will bring it to pass very soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let Pharaoh select a wise, discerning person to place in charge over the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, let Pharaoh immediately proceed to appoint supervisors over the land of Egypt, who will collect one fifth of its agricultural production during the coming seven years of abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them collect all the food during the coming fruitful years, store up the grain in cities governed by Pharaoh’s authority, and place it under guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the food be kept in reserve to feed the land for the seven years of famine that will occur throughout Egypt, so the people don’t die during the famine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What Joseph proposed pleased Pharaoh and all of his advisors,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Pharaoh asked his servants, “Can we find anyone else like this—someone in whom the Spirit of God lives?
speaker: Narrator

text: Since God has revealed all of this to you,” Pharaoh told Joseph, “there is no one so wise and discerning as you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to be appointed in charge over my palace, and all of my people are to do whatever you command them to do. Only the throne will have greater authority than you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” Pharaoh confirmed to Joseph, “I’ve put you in charge of the entire land of Egypt!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh removed his signet ring from his hand, placed it on Joseph’s hand, had him clothed in fine linen garments, and placed a gold chain around his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he provided him with a chariot as his second-in-command, outfitted with a group of people who shouted out in front of him, “Bow your knees!” And that’s how Pharaoh set Joseph over the entire land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh also told Joseph, “I’m still Pharaoh, but without your permission nobody in all of the land of Egypt will so much as lift up their hands or take a step!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh also changed Joseph’s name to Zaphenath-paneah and gave Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On, to him as his wife. And that’s how Joseph gained authority over the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was 30 years old when he began to serve Pharaoh, king of Egypt, by traveling throughout the land of Egypt, independent from Pharaoh’s oversight.
speaker: Narrator

text: While bumper crops grew during the seven abundant years,
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph collected the surplus food throughout the land of Egypt, storing food in cities; that is, he gathered the food from fields that surrounded every city and stored it there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph stored up so much grain—like sand on the seashore in so much abundance!—that he stopped keeping records because it was proving to be impossible to measure how much they were gathering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before the years of famine arrived, Joseph fathered two sons with Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph named his firstborn son Manasseh because, he said, “God has made me forget all of my hard life and my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He named his second son Ephraim because, he said, “God has made me fruitful in the land of my troubles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the seven years of abundance throughout the land of Egypt ended,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seven years of famine started, just as Joseph had predicted. It was an international famine, but there was food everywhere throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, the land of Egypt began to feel the effects of the famine, so the people cried out to Pharaoh for food. “Go see Joseph,” Pharaoh announced to all the Egyptians, “and do whatever he tells you to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph opened all of the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, because the famine was beginning to be severe throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, all of the surrounding nations came to Joseph to buy grain from Egypt, because the famine had become severe throughout the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Jacob observed that there was grain in Egypt, so he asked his sons, “Why do you keep on staring at one another?
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay attention now! I’ve heard that there is grain in Egypt, so go down there and buy some grain for us, so we can live, instead of dying.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So ten of Joseph’s brothers left to buy grain from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob would not send Joseph’s brother Benjamin to accompany them, because he was saying, “I’m afraid that he’ll come to some kind of harm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel’s sons went in a caravan that included others who were going to Egypt to buy grain, because the famine pervaded the land of Canaan, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Joseph continued to be ruler over the land, in charge of selling to everyone in the land. Joseph’s brothers appeared and bowed down to him, face down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As soon as Joseph saw his brothers, he knew who they were, but he remained disguised and asked them gruffly, “Where are you from?”
“From the land of Canaan,” they replied. “We’re here to buy food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph had already recognized his brothers, even though they had not recognized him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, Joseph remembered the dreams that he had about them. So he accused them, “You’re spies! You’ve come here to spy on our undefended territories!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, your majesty,” they replied. “Your servants have come here to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: We’re all sons of a common father. We’re honest men, your majesty. We’re not spies!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph kept insisting, “It’s just as I’ve said—you’ve come here to spy on our unguarded territories!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But your majesty,” they pleaded, “your servants include twelve brothers, the sons of a common father back in the land of Canaan. Please! Our youngest brother remains with our father, and the other one is no longer alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m right!” Joseph insisted. “Just as I said, you’re spies!
speaker: Narrator

text: So here’s how we’ll test you. You can bet the life of Pharaoh that you’re not leaving here until your youngest brother comes here!
speaker: Narrator

text: One of you is to be sent back so he can get your brother while the rest of you remain in custody. That way, we’ll test whether or not you’re telling the truth. If you’re not, as surely as the Pharaoh lives, you’re spies!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph locked them all together in prison for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, Joseph told them, “I fear God, so do this and you’ll live.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you’re honest men, leave one of your brothers here in custody, then the rest of you can leave and take some grain with you to alleviate the famine that’s affecting your households.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just be sure to bring your youngest brother back to me so what you’ve claimed can be verified. That way, you won’t die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We’re all guilty because of what we did to our brother!” they told each other. “We kept on watching his suffering while he pleaded with us! We’re in this mess because we wouldn’t listen!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Didn’t I tell you!” Reuben replied. “‘Don’t wrong the kid!’ I said, but would you listen? No! Now it’s payback time!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, they had no idea that Joseph could understand them, since he was talking to them through an interpreter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He turned away from them and began to weep.
When he returned, he spoke with them, but then he took Simeon away from them and had him placed under arrest right in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Joseph gave orders to fill up their sacks with grain, to return each man’s money to his own sack, and to supply each of them with provisions for their return journey. All of this was done for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they each mounted up, their donkeys having been loaded with grain, and left from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, one of them opened up his sack to give his donkey some fodder after they had stopped at the place where they intended to lodge for the night. There, in the mouth of his sack, was all of his money!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He reported to his brothers, “My money has been returned! It’s right here in my sack!”
Trembling with mounting consternation, each of them asked one another, “What is God doing to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they had returned to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him everything that had happened to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who was in charge of the land spoke harshly to us,” they said. “He accused us of being spies!
speaker: Narrator

text: But we told him, ‘No! We’re honest men! We’re not spies!
speaker: Narrator

text: Our father has twelve sons, but one of us isn’t alive anymore, and our youngest brother is with our father today back home in Canaan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man who was in charge of the land responded, ‘I’m going to test your honesty. Leave one of your brothers with me, take some grain for the famine that’s afflicting your households, and leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: But bring your youngest brother back to me so I can be sure that you’re honest men, and not spies. Then I’ll return your brother to you, and you’ll be allowed to trade anywhere in the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, as they went about unloading their sacks, each man’s bundle of money was found in each man’s sack. When they and their father saw their bundles of money, they were greatly distressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father Jacob told them, “You’re causing me to lose my children! Joseph is gone. Now Simeon is gone, and you’re planning to take Benjamin, too. Everything’s going against me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Feel free to put my own two sons to death,” Reuben responded to his father, “if I don’t bring him back to you. Trust me—I’ll bring him back to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob replied, “My son isn’t going back with you, since his brother is dead and he’s the only one left. If something should harm him as you travel, then it’ll be death for me and my sad, gray hair!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the famine remained severe throughout the region.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, when Jacob’s family was beginning to eat the last of the grain that they had brought back from Egypt, their father Jacob told his sons, “Go back to Egypt and buy us some food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Judah reminded him, “The man distinctly warned us: ‘You’ll never see my face unless your brother comes with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you send our brother with us, we’ll go down and buy some food.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t send him, we’re not going, because the man told us, ‘You’ll never see my face unless your brother is with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel replied, “Why did you make all this trouble by telling the man that you have another brother?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man specifically asked about us and our relatives,” they responded. “He asked us, ‘Is your father still alive?’ and ‘Do you have another brother?’ So we answered his questions. How could we have known that he would tell us to bring our brother back with us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send the young man with me,” Judah told his father Israel, “and we’ll get up and go so we can survive and not die—and that includes all of us, you and our families.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll even offer myself to guarantee that I’ll be responsible for him. If I don’t bring him back and present him to you, I’ll personally bear the consequences forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, if we hadn’t delayed, we could have been there and back twice by now!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If that’s the way it has to be,” their father Israel replied, “then do this: take some of the best produce of the land in your containers and take them to the man as a gift—some resin ointment, some honey, fragrant resins, myrrh, pistachios, and almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take twice as much money with you so you can return the money that had been replaced in the mouth of your sacks. Maybe it was an accounting mistake on his part.
speaker: Narrator

text: And be sure to take your brother, too. So get up, return to the man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and may God Almighty cause the man to show compassion toward you. May he send all of you back, including your other brother and Benjamin. Now as for me, if I lose my children, I lose them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men took their gift and twice as much money, got up, took Benjamin with them, and set out for Egypt. Eventually they appeared before Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Joseph noticed that Benjamin had come with them, he ordered his palace manager, “Bring the men into the palace. Slaughter an animal and prepare it, because these men will be dining with me for lunch.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man did what Joseph had ordered, and brought the men to Joseph’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were terrified as they were being taken to Joseph’s palace. “It’s because of that money that was returned to our sacks the first time we were brought to him,” they reasoned. “He’s seeking an excuse to attack us, enslave us, and confiscate our donkeys!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they approached Joseph’s palace manager and talked with him at the palace entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your Excellency,” they said, “The first time we came here to buy food,
speaker: Narrator

text: when we arrived at our overnight lodging place, we opened our sacks and discovered each man’s money was still in the mouth of his sack. All of our money was there! We’ve brought it back with us in full.
speaker: Narrator

text: We’ve also brought along some more money to buy supplies, but we don’t know who put our money back into our sacks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Relax,” the manager said. “You can stop being afraid, now. Your God, the God of your father, has placed hidden treasure within those sacks for you. I’ve been paid in full.” Then he brought Simeon out to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: ushered the men into Joseph’s palace, gave them water to wash their feet, and provided fodder for their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then off he went to prepare the honorary meal that was to be made ready for Joseph’s arrival at noon, since they had been informed that they were going to be eating there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph arrived at his palace, his brothers brought to him their gifts that they had carried with them and bowed to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph asked them how they had been doing. “Is your father well, the older gentleman about whom you spoke?” he inquired. “Is he still alive?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your servant, our father, is doing well,” they replied. “He is still alive.” Then they bowed down in humility.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Joseph looked up and recognized his brother Benjamin, his own mother’s son, he asked, “Is this your youngest brother about whom you spoke to me?” And he addressed him directly, “May God be gracious to you, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Joseph hurried out, deeply moved because of his brother, and looked for a place to weep by himself. He entered his personal quarters, wept there awhile,
speaker: Narrator

text: then washed his face and came out. Barely controlling himself, he ordered his staff to serve the meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s staff served him by himself, his brothers separately, and the Egyptian staff members by themselves, because the Egyptians wouldn’t take their meal with the Hebrews, since doing so was detestable for the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the brothers were seated in front of Joseph in birth order, from firstborn to youngest. The men stared at one another in astonishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph himself brought portions to them from his own table, except that he provided to Benjamin five times as much as he did for each of the others. So they feasted together and drank freely with Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Joseph commanded his palace manager, “Fill the men’s sacks to full capacity with food and replace each man’s money at the top of the sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then place my cup—the silver one—in the top of the sack belonging to the youngest one, along with the money he brought to buy grain.” So the manager did precisely what Joseph told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning, the men were sent on their way, along with their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had not traveled far from the city when Joseph ordered his palace manager, “Get up, follow those men, and when you’ve caught up with them, ask them, ‘Why did you repay evil for good?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you have the cup that my master uses to drink from and also uses to practice divination? You’re wrong to have done this.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went after them and made that accusation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your Excellency,” they replied, “Why do you speak like this? Far be it from your servants to act like this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, we brought back to you from the land of Canaan the money that we found at the top of our sacks. How, then, could we have stolen silver or gold from your master’s palace?
speaker: Narrator

text: Go ahead and execute whichever one of your servants is discovered to have it, and we’ll remain as your master’s slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Agreed,” he responded. “Just as you’ve said, the one who is found to have it in his possession will become my slave, and the rest of you will be innocent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they quickly dismounted, unloaded their sacks onto the ground, and each one of them opened his own sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: The palace manager searched for the cup, beginning with the oldest brother’s sack and ending with the youngest brother’s sack, and there it was!—in Benjamin’s sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, they all tore their clothes, reloaded their donkeys, and returned to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was waiting for them back at his palace when his brothers returned. They fell to the ground in front of him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Joseph asked them, “Why did you do this? Don’t you know that I’m an expert at divination?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What can we say, Your Excellency?” Judah replied. “How can we explain this or justify ourselves? God has discovered the sin of your servants, and now we’ve become slaves to you, Your Excellency, both we and the one in whose possession the cup has been discovered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Far be it from me to do this,” Joseph responded. “The man in whose possession the cup was discovered will be my slave, but the rest of you may leave in peace to be with your father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Judah approached him and begged him, “Your Excellency, please allow your servant to speak to you privately. Please don’t be angry with your servant, since you are equal to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your Excellency asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or brother?’
speaker: Narrator

text: and we answered Your Excellency, ‘We have an aged father and a younger child who was born when he was old. His brother is now dead, so he’s the only surviving son of his mother. His father loves him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But then you ordered your servants, ‘Bring him here to me so I can see him for myself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we told Your Excellency, ‘The young man cannot leave his father, because if he were to do so, his father would die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But then you told your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes back with you, you won’t see my face again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, after we had gone back to your servant, my father, we told him what Your Excellency had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Go back,’ our father ordered, ‘and buy us a little food.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But we told him, ‘We can’t go back there. If our youngest brother accompanies us, we’ll go back, but we cannot see the man’s face again unless our youngest brother accompanies us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then your servant, our father, told us, ‘You know my wife bore me two sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them left me, so I concluded “I’m certain that he has been torn to pieces,” and I haven’t seen him since then.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you take this one from me, too, and then something harmful happens to him, then it will be death for me and my sad, gray hair!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So when I go back to your servant, my father, and the young man isn’t with us, since he’s constantly living life focused on his son,
speaker: Narrator

text: when he notices that the young man hasn’t come back with us, he’ll die, and your servants really will have brought death to your servant, our father, along with his sad, gray hair!
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, your servant pledged his own life as a guarantee of the young man’s safety. I told my father, ‘If I don’t bring him back to you, you can blame me forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, please allow your servant to remain as a slave to Your Excellency, instead of the young man, and let the young man go back home with his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, how can I go back to my father if the young man doesn’t accompany me? I’m afraid of what might happen to my father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, Joseph could not control his emotions any longer, so he cried out to everyone who was standing nearby, “Everybody! Leave me!” As a result, none of his staff was anywhere near him when he revealed himself to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried so loudly that the Egyptians heard him, including Pharaoh’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph blurted out, “I’m Joseph! Is my father really alive?” But his brothers could not answer him, because they had become terrified to be in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph implored his brothers, “Please come close to me.” So they did.
“I’m your brother Joseph, whom you sold into slavery in Egypt!” he told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But don’t be distressed or angry at yourselves because you sold me here, because God sent me ahead of you all in order to deliver us.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s because this famine has been going on for two years now in this region, and there are still five years left, during which there won’t be any plowing or harvesting.
speaker: Narrator

text: God sent me ahead of you to keep you alive on the earth, and to save you all in a magnificent way.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, it wasn’t you who sent me here, but God himself! He established me as a father-figure to Pharaoh himself! I’m in charge of his entire palace and ruler over the entire land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So hurry up, go back to my father, and tell him that his son Joseph tells him, ‘God has made me master of all of Egypt. Hurry up! Come live with me!’
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to live in the land of Goshen, near where I am—you, your children, your grandchildren, your flocks, your herds, and everything that you own.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll provide for you there, since there are still five years of famine left to go, and you, your households, and everything you own would have otherwise become impoverished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, now! All of you can see me! And my own brother Benjamin can tell that it’s really me speaking to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: So go tell my father about all of my splendor in Egypt. Tell him about everything that you’ve seen. Be quick about it, and bring my father down here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he threw his arms around Benjamin and wept as they embraced.
speaker: Narrator

text: He kissed all of his brothers and wept with them, too, and then his brothers were able to talk with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the news reached Pharaoh’s palace that Joseph’s brothers had arrived, Pharaoh and his servants were ecstatic.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh told Joseph, “Be sure to tell your brothers, ‘Do this: load up your livestock, go back to the land of Canaan,
speaker: Narrator

text: get your father and your households, and come back to me. I’ll give you the best of the land of Egypt and you can live off the abundance of the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition,” Pharaoh ordered, “Do this: take some transport wagons from the land of Egypt for your little ones to ride in, along with your wives, and bring your father and come!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t worry about your household goods, because the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel’s sons did what they were asked to do, and Joseph provided wagons for them, as Pharaoh had commanded. He also gave them provisions for the journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave each of them some changes of clothes, but he also gave Benjamin 300 pieces of silver and five changes of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent his father ten male donkeys loaded with the best of Egyptian goods and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, bread, and provisions for his father during the journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph sent his brothers away, and they left for home. As they were leaving, Joseph admonished them, “Don’t quarrel on the way back!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph’s brothers left Egypt and returned to the land of Canaan and to their father Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text: where they informed their father, “Joseph is still alive! As a matter of fact, he’s ruling the entire land of Egypt.” But Jacob didn’t believe them, because he had become cynical.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, as soon as his sons had told him everything Joseph had said, and after he saw the wagons that Joseph had sent along to carry him, their father Jacob’s spirit was encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s enough,” Israel replied. “My son Joseph is still alive. I’m going to go see him before I die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Israel began his journey, taking along everything that he owned, and arrived at Beer-sheba, where he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God spoke to Israel through night visions, addressing him, “Jacob! Jacob!”
“Here I am!” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m God, your father’s God. Don’t be afraid to move down to Egypt, because I’m going to turn you into a mighty nation there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going down with you to Egypt, and I’m certainly going to bring you back again. And Joseph himself will be with you when you die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob got up and left Beer-sheba, and Israel’s sons carried their father Jacob, their little ones, and their wives in the transport wagons that Pharaoh had sent to carry them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their livestock and their household property that they had acquired in the land of Canaan and traveled to Egypt. Jacob and all of his descendants went with him—
speaker: Narrator

text: including his sons, his grandsons, his daughters, and his granddaughters—every one of his descendants accompanied him to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s a list of the names of Israel’s sons, that is, of Jacob and his sons who moved to Egypt: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn;
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben’s sons Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi;
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon’s sons Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, who was the son of a Canaanite woman;
speaker: Narrator

text: Levi’s sons Gershon, Kohath, and Merari;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Judah’s sons Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah. (Technically, Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan.) Perez’s sons were Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also included were Issachar’s sons Tola, Puvvah, Job, and Shimron;
speaker: Narrator

text: along with Zebulun’s sons Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were all sons from Leah, whom she bore for Jacob in Paddan-aram, along with his daughter Dinah. He had 33 sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also included were Gad’s sons Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli;
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher’s sons Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and their sister Serah. Beriah’s sons Heber and Malchiel were also included.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were all sons from Zilpah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Leah. She bore these sixteen children for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob’s wife Rachel’s sons were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s sons born in the land of Egypt were Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On, bore for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin’s sons included Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were all the sons of Rachel, who were born for Jacob—fourteen in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also included were Dan’s son Hushim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali’s sons Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were sons of Bilhah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Rachel. She bore these children for Jacob—seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these people, who belonged to Jacob’s family, traveled to Egypt. All of Jacob’s direct descendants, not including his sons’ wives, numbered 66 persons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph had two sons born to him in Egypt, and all of Jacob’s household who went to Egypt numbered 70.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent Judah ahead of them to meet with Joseph, who would be guiding them to Goshen, and so they arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph prepared his chariot and went to meet his father Israel in Goshen. As soon as Jacob appeared in his presence, he embraced him and wept for a long time as he held on to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now let me die,” Israel told Joseph, “since I’ve seen your face and confirmed that you’re still alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph addressed his brothers and his father’s household and told them, “I’ll go up and tell Pharaoh that my brothers and my father’s household have arrived from Canaan to be with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll mention that the men are shepherds. Because they’ve been taking care of livestock, they brought along their flocks, their herds, and everything else that they own.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh calls for you and asks you ‘What’s your occupation?’
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to tell him, ‘Your servants have been taking care of livestock since we were youths. We and our ancestors have taken care of livestock.’ That way, you’ll be able to live in the Goshen territory, since shepherds are detestable to the Egyptians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Joseph went to inform Pharaoh. “My father and brothers have come here from Canaan,” he said, “and they’ve come with their flocks, herds, and everything else they have. I settled them in the Goshen territory!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought along five of his brothers to present before Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pharaoh asked his brothers, “What are your occupations?”
“Your servants are shepherds,” they replied, “both we and our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: We’ve come to live for a while in this region, since there is no pasture back in Canaan for your servants’ flocks. May your servants please live in the Goshen territory?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh replied to Joseph, “Now that your father and your brothers have come to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: Egypt is at your disposal, so settle your father and brothers in the best part of the land! Let them live in the Goshen territory. If you learn that any of them are especially skilled, put them in charge of my livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Joseph brought his father Jacob to Pharaoh and introduced him. Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How old are you?” Pharaoh asked Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m 130 years old,” Jacob replied. “My years have turned out to be few and unpleasant, but I haven’t yet reached the age my ancestors did during their travels on earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and then left the throne room.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph settled his father and brothers, assigning them their own land in the best part of Egypt (in the territory of Rameses), just as Pharaoh had ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph provided food for his father, his brothers, and all of his father’s household, proportionate to the number of young children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, there continued to be no food throughout the land, because the famine remained very severe. As a result, both Egypt and Canaan languished under the effects of the famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph kept on accumulating all the money that was to be found throughout Egypt and Canaan in exchange for the grain that was being purchased. He stored the money in Pharaoh’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all the money had been spent throughout Egypt and Canaan, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and demanded, “Give us food! Why should we die right in front of you? Our money is spent!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You can surrender your livestock,” Joseph replied. “I’ll feed them in exchange, since your money is gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph traded food in exchange for horses, various flocks and herds, and donkeys. He fed them with food in exchange for their livestock during that year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following year, they came to him and reminded him, “We won’t hide from you, your Excellency, that we’ve spent all of our money, and that our livestock all belong to you. There’s nothing left to trade with you, your Excellency, except our bodies and our territories.
speaker: Narrator

text: So why should we and our land die right in front of you? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we and our land will be slaves to Pharaoh. Give us seed, so we can survive and not die, and so the land won’t stay desolate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph purchased all of the Egyptian territory for Pharaoh. Every Egyptian sold his field, because the famine’s effect was so severe. That’s how Pharaoh came to own the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph transported the people to cities from one end of Egypt to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, he did not purchase land belonging to the priests, because the priests held an allotment, previously provided to them by Pharaoh, from which they lived. That’s why they did not sell their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Joseph addressed the people. “Pay attention,” he said. “I’ve bought you and your land for Pharaoh today, in exchange for seed for you. Now go sow the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When harvest season arrives, you are to provide a fifth of the harvest to Pharaoh. The remaining four fifths are to be for your use, for seed, and to feed you, your households, and your little ones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’ve saved our lives,” they replied. “If it pleases you, your Excellency, we’ll be Pharaoh’s slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph crafted a statute concerning Egypt that remains valid to this day that Pharaoh should own a fifth of the produce, excluding the land belonging to the priests, which remained outside of Pharaoh’s control.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel remained in Egypt’s Goshen territory, acquired land there, became prosperous, and his descendants grew very numerous.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived for seventeen more years in Egypt, until he was 147 years old.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time approached for Israel to die, he called for his son Joseph and addressed him. “Please,” he asked, “if you’re happy with me, make a solemn promise that you’ll treat me fairly and kindly by not burying me in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, when I’ve died, as my ancestors have, you are to carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their tomb.”
“I’ll do what you’ve asked,” Joseph replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Promise me,” Israel insisted. So Joseph promised. Then Israel collapsed on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, somebody informed Joseph, “Your father is ill!” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim with him to visit Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Jacob was informed, “Look! Your son Joseph has come to visit you,” Israel rallied his strength and sat up in bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob reminded Joseph, “God Almighty revealed himself to me at Luz in Canaan and blessed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told me, ‘Pay attention! I’m going to make you fruitful and numerous. I’m going to build you into a vast nation of people and then I’ll give this land to your descendants for an eternal possession.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You have two sons who were born to you in Egypt before I came to be with you, whom I now take as my own. Ephraim and Manasseh are mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your descendants are to be reckoned as yours, but are to be referred to among the names of their brothers in their respective inheritances.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as for me, Rachel died after I arrived in Canaan from Paddan, much to my sorrow. While I was on my journey to Ephrathah (also known as Bethlehem), I buried her there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, Israel saw Joseph’s sons and asked, “Who are these?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“These are my sons,” Joseph replied. “God gave them to me here in Egypt.”
“Please bring them close to me,” Jacob said, “so I can bless them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel’s eyesight had become poor from age. Because he couldn’t see well, Joseph brought them close to him, and Israel kissed them both and embraced them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told Joseph, “I never thought I’d see you again, and now God has allowed me to see your children as well!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph took them off his knees and then bowed low with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought them both close to his father, placing Ephraim with his right hand toward Israel’s left and Manasseh with his left hand toward Israel’s right.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel stretched out his right hand, laying it on Ephraim’s head (he was the younger son) and laying his left hand on Manasseh’s head (even though Manasseh was the firstborn).
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Israel blessed Joseph by saying:
“May the God in whose presence
    my ancestors Abraham and Isaac walked,
the God who has continued shepherding me
    my whole life even until today,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the angel who has been rescuing me
    from all sorts of evil,
        bless these young men.
May my name continue to live on within them,
    including the names
        of my ancestors Abraham and Isaac,
and may they grow into a vast multitude
    throughout the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph observed that his father had laid his right hand on Ephraim’s head. That displeased him, so he grabbed his father’s hand and started to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, father, this one is the firstborn. Place your right hand on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father refused. “I know,” he said. “I know. He’s going to produce a large nation, and he’s going to be very great. However, his younger brother will become even greater than he, and his descendants will become a multitude of nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
That very day, Jacob blessed them with this blessing:
“By you Israel will extend this blessing:
    ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh!’”
By doing this, he placed Ephraim before Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel told Joseph, “Pay attention! I’m about to die, but God will be with you. He’ll bring you back to the land that belongs to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m assigning you one portion more than your brothers from the land that I confiscated from the control of the Amorites in battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jacob called his sons together and told them, “Assemble yourselves around me so I can tell you all what is going to happen to you in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Gather together and listen,
    you children of Jacob.
        Listen to your father Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Reuben, you’re my firstborn,
    my strength,
        and the first fruit of my vitality.
You excel in rank
    and excel in power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you’re as undisciplined as a roaring river,
    so eventually you won’t succeed,
because you got in your father’s bed,
    defiled it, and then approached my couch.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Simeon and Levi are brothers;
    their swords are violent weapons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll never join their council;
    I’ll never enter their assembly.
In their anger they committed murder
    and lamed cattle just for fun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their anger is cursed,
    because it is so fierce,
as is their vehemence,
    because it is so cruel.
I will separate them throughout Jacob’s territory
    and disperse them throughout Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Your brothers will praise you, Judah.
    Your hand will be at the throat of your enemies,
and your father’s children will bow down to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah is a lion cub.
    My son, you have gone up from the prey.
Crouching like a lion,
    he lies down,
Like a lioness,
    who would dare rouse him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The scepter will not depart from Judah,
    nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet,
until the one comes, who owns them both,
    and to him will belong the allegiance of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Binding his donkey to the vine
    and his mare’s foal to its thick tendrils,
he will wash his garments in wine
    and his robe in the juice of grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes are darker than wine
    and his teeth whiter than milk.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Zebulun will settle down near the sea shore
    and become a safe haven for shipping,
        bordering Sidon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Issachar is a strong donkey,
    resting between sheepfolds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He observed that his resting place was excellent,
    and that the land was pleasant;
he bent down,
    picked up his burdens,
        and became a slave at forced labor.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Dan will judge his people
    as one of Israel’s tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dan will be a snake on the path,
    a viper on the road
that snaps at the heels of horses,
    causing their riders to fall off.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lord, I’m waiting for your salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bandits will raid Gad,
    but Gad will raid them back.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Asher’s food will be delicious;
    he will be a provider of delicacies fit for royalty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Naphtali is a free running deer
    who produces eloquent literature.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Joseph is descended from a fruitful vine,
    a fruitful vine planted near springs of water.
        His branches climb over walls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even though enemies attacked him,
    shooting at him
        and pursuing him viciously,
speaker: Narrator

text:
nevertheless his bow remained steady
    and his arms kept in shape
        by the strength of Jacob’s Mighty One,
in the name of the Shepherd,
    Israel’s Rock,
speaker: Narrator

text:
by your father’s God
    who helps you,
by the Almighty
    who will keep on blessing you
with blessings from heaven above,
    with blessings from the deepest ocean,
with blessing from the breasts and the womb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your father’s blessings will prove to be stronger
    than blessings from the eternal mountains
        or bounties from the everlasting hills.
May they come to rest on Joseph’s head,
    May they be set upon the brow of the one
        who was separated from his own brothers.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: That’s how Israel blessed these twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father told them when he pronounced his blessing for them, blessing each one with a blessing suitable for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his last words, Jacob issued this set of instructions to them all: “I’m about to join our ancestors. Bury me alongside my ancestors in the cave in the field that used to belong to Ephron the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s the cave in the field near Mamre at Machpelah in the land of Canaan that Abraham bought to serve as a cemetery.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s where Abraham and his wife Sarah were buried, where Isaac and his wife Rebekah were buried, and where I buried Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the field and the cave that’s in it were purchased from the Hittites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After concluding this set of instructions to his sons, Jacob tucked his feet up into bed, quit breathing, and was gathered to his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph embraced his father, cried over him, and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, he issued orders to his physician servants to embalm his father. So they embalmed Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It took 40 days to complete the process, the normal period required for embalming. Meanwhile, the Egyptians mourned for him for 70 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the conclusion of the mourning period, Joseph addressed Pharaoh’s household. “If you’re satisfied with me, would you please take this message to Pharaoh for me? Tell him,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My father told me, “Look! I’m about to die. Bury me in my grave that I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.” So please let me travel to bury my father. I’ll be right back.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please go,” Pharaoh replied. “Bury your father, as he asked you to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph got up and went to bury his father, accompanied by all of Pharaoh’s servants, all of the elders of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: all of Joseph’s household, his brothers, and his father’s household. They left behind in the territory of Goshen only their youngest children, their flocks, and their herds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chariots and horsemen also accompanied Joseph, so there were a lot of people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at Atad’s threshing floor, which is located beyond the Jordan River, they held a great and mournful memorial service, during which Joseph spent seven days mourning for his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the Canaanites who lived in the land observed the mourning going on at Atad’s threshing floor, they commented “This is a significant time of mourning for the Egyptians.” That’s why the place, which is located beyond the Jordan River, became known as Abel-mizraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so Israel’s sons did what he had instructed them to do:
speaker: Narrator

text: they carried him to the territory of Canaan and buried him in the cave in Machpelah field near Mamre that Abraham had purchased as a cemetery from Ephron the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had buried his father, Joseph and his brothers returned to Egypt, along with everyone who had gone with him to attend the burial.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, after Joseph’s brothers faced the reality of their father’s death, they asked themselves, “What happens if Joseph decides to hold a grudge against us? What if he pays us back in full for all the wrong things we did to him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent this message to Joseph:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Before he died, your father left some instructions. He told us, ‘Tell Joseph, “Please forgive your brothers’ offenses. I beg you, forgive their sins, because they wronged you.”’ So please forgive the transgression of the servants of your father’s God.”
Joseph wept when they talked to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph’s brothers went to visit him, fell prostrate in front of him, and declared, “Look! We’re your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be afraid,” Joseph responded. “Am I sitting in God’s place?
speaker: Narrator

text: As far as you’re concerned, you were planning evil against me, but God intended it for good, planning to bring about the present result so that many people would be preserved alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: So don’t be afraid! I’ll take care of you and your little ones.” So Joseph kept on comforting them, speaking to the needs of their hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph continued to live in Egypt, along with his father’s household, until he was 110 years old.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph saw the third generation of Ephraim’s children, as well as the children who had been born to Manasseh’s son Machir, whom he adopted as his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Joseph told his brothers, “I’m going to die soon, but God will certainly provide for you and bring you up from this land to the land that he promised with an oath to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph made all of Israel’s other children make this promise: “Because God is certainly going to take care of you, you are to carry my bones up from here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Joseph died at the age of 110 years, and he was embalmed and placed in a coffin in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
